He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have stalled.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans -- although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. {"timeCrawl": "18:12:00", "uri": "711040585", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T18:12:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "ProSoccerTalk", "uri": "soccer.nbcsports.com", "id": "886"}, "url": "http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2017/08/17/previewing-all-10-premier-league-games-week-2-video/", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3371616", "body": "Spanish forward Jese will attempt to relaunch his stuttering career in England after leaving Paris Saint-Germain to become the latest Champions League winner at Stoke.\n\nThe 24-year-old Jese joined Stoke on a season-long loan after failing to settle at PSG following his move from Real Madrid for a reported $29 million in August 2016. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have stalled.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans -- although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. Image courtesy: Twitter @premierleague\n\nThe 24-year-old Spanish youth international only joined PSG from Real Madrid a year ago but failed to establish himself in the French capital and spent the second half of last season on loan at his native Las Palmas.\n\nHe won the Champions League twice with Real and was top scorer when Spain lifted the European Under-19 Championship in 2012.\n\nHe is Stoke manager Mark Hughes's sixth signing of the season joining the likes of Darren Fletcher, Kurt Zouma, Maxim Choupa-Moting, Bruno Martins Indi and Josh Tymon at The Potters.\n\nJese will replace fellow Spanish forward Joselu in the Stoke squad after the latter agreed on Wednesday to join Newcastle United for a reported \u00a35m.\n\nJese scored 12 goals in 63 La Liga appearances for Real before joining PSG for 25 million euros ($29 million) but his chances of forcing his way into the Parisian first team slimmed following the world record signing of Brazilian superstar Neymar.\n\nPSG insisted, though, that Jese could yet feature in their future plans and that the loan doesn't include a clause to make the move permanent.\n\n\"The loan to Stoke City doesn't include an option to buy. Jese is under contract with Paris Saint-Germain until 2021,\" said the Ligue 1 giants.\n\nThe signing of Neymar means several more players are likely to leave PSG before the transfer window shuts on 31 August.\n\nFrench international forward Hatem Ben Arfa and Polish international midfielder Grzegorz Krychowiak, both signed a year ago, are rumoured to be on their way out after failing to impress PSG coach Unai Emery.\n\nFrance midfielder Blaise Matuidi is believed to be heading to Italian champions Juventus while controversial Ivory Coast full-back Serge Aurier could also be on his way.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 16, 2017 04:29 pm | Updated Date: Aug 16, 2017 04:29 pm\n\nTags :#Football#Jese rodriguez#Kickingaround#Ligue 1#Paris-saint germain#Premier league#Stoke city", "id": {"timeCrawl": "13:48:00", "uri": "710350194", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T13:48:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4795982/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3360188", "body": "Spanish forward Jese will attempt to relaunch his stuttering career in England after leaving Paris Saint-Germain to become the latest Champions League winner at Stoke on Wednesday.\n\nThe 24-year-old Jese joined Stoke on a season-long loan after failing to settle at PSG following his move from Real Madrid for a reported 25 million euros ($29 million) in August 2016. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nAlso, Swansea playmaker Gylfi Sigurdsson is close to sealing a drawn-out transfer to Everton after completing a medical examination. Everton is reportedly paying 45 million pounds ($58 million) for the Iceland international, wo would be a fourth attacking player to arrive at Goodison Park this summer after Wayne Rooney, Sandro Ramirez and Davy Klaassen.\n\nFILE - In this Aug. 21, 2016 file photo, PSG's Jese Rodriguez reacts before the French League One soccer match between PSG and Metz at the Parc des Princes stadium in Paris. Paris Saint-Germain says Wednesday Aug. 16, 2017 it is loaning Spanish forward Jese Rodriguez to Stoke City for this season, without the option to buy him. (AP Photo/Kamil Zihnioglu, File)\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have stalled.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans - although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. At Las Palmas, Jese scored three goals in 13 games.\n\nJese is Stoke's sixth signing of the summer transfer window.\n\n___\n\nMore AP Premier League coverage: (Source: AP) Neymar might have to wait longer for PSG debutPSG recover 1 million euros even before Neymar kicks ballLuis Suarez posts emotional goodbye to 'brother' Neymar\n\nSpanish forward Jese will attempt to relaunch his stuttering career in England after leaving Paris Saint-Germain to become the latest Champions League winner at Stoke on Wednesday.\n\nThe 24-year-old Jese joined Stoke on a season-long loan after failing to settle at PSG following his move from Real Madrid for a reported 25 million euros ($29 million) in August 2016. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nAlso, Swansea playmaker Gylfi Sigurdsson is close to sealing a drawn-out transfer to Everton after completing a medical examination. Everton is reportedly paying 45 million pounds ($58 million) for the Iceland international, wo would be a fourth attacking player to arrive at Goodison Park this summer after Wayne Rooney, Sandro Ramirez and Davy Klaassen.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have stalled.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday. Jese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute. Although technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. At Las Palmas, Jese scored three goals in 13 games.\n\nJese is Stoke's sixth signing of the summer transfer window.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Paris Saint He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have dipped.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans - although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. At Las Palmas, Jese scored three goals in 13 games.\n\nJese is Stoke's sixth signing of the summer transfer window.\n\n___\n\nMore AP Premier League coverage: forcing his way into the Parisian first team slimmed following the world record signing of Brazilian superstar Neymar.\n\nPSG insisted, though, that Jese could yet feature in their future plans and "Spanish forward Jese has joined Stoke City on a season-long loan from Paris Saint-Germain, the two clubs announced on Wednesday.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" said Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes.\n\n\"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nThe 24-year-old Spanish youth international only joined PSG from Real Madrid a year ago but failed to establish himself in the French capital and spent the second half of last season on loan at his native Las Palmas.\n\nHe won the Champions League twice with Real and was top scorer when Spain lifted the European Under-19 Championship in 2012.\n\nHe is Stoke manager Mark Hughes's sixth signing of the season joining the likes of Darren Fletcher, Kurt Zouma, Maxim Choupa-Moting, Bruno Martins Indi and Josh Tymon at The Potters.\n\nJese will replace fellow Spanish forward Joselu in the Stoke squad after the latter agreed on Wednesday to join Newcastle United for a reported \u00a35m.\n\nJese scored 12 goals in 63 La Liga appearances for Real before joining PSG for 25 million euros ($29 million) but his chances of forcing his way into the Parisian first team slimmed following the world record signing of Brazilian superstar Neymar.\n\nPSG insisted, though, that Jese could yet feature in their future plans and that the loan doesn't include a clause to make the move permanent.\n\n\"The loan to Stoke City doesn't include an option to buy. {"timeCrawl": "16:51:00", "uri": "710439657", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:51:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Shanghai Daily", "uri": "shanghaidaily.com", "id": "3175"}, "url": "http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sports/soccer/PSG-sends-ace-Jese-out-on-loan-to-Stoke/shdaily.shtml", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3360188", "body": "SPAIN forward Jese will attempt to relaunch his stuttering career in England after leaving Paris Saint-Germain to become the latest UEFA Champions League winner at Stoke City yesterday.\n\nThe 24-year-old Jese joined Stoke on a season-long loan after failing to settle at PSG following his move from Real Madrid for a reported 25 million euros (US$29 million) in August 2016. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nAlso, Swansea playmaker Gylfi Sigurdsson sealed a drawn-out transfer to Everton after completing a medical examination. Everton is reportedly paying 45 million pounds (US$58 million) for the Iceland international, who would be a fourth attacking player to arrive at Goodison Park this summer after Wayne Rooney, Sandro Ramirez and Davy Klaassen.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the English Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have dipped.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have UCL winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their UCL-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said.\n\n\"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham United. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle United for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 0-1 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans -- although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. {"timeCrawl": "20:31:00", "uri": "710530885", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:31:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/english-soccer/everton-complete-49m-swoop-for-swansea-s-gylfi-sigurdsson-1.3188934", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Everton have completed the club-record signing of Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea, for a fee believed to be around \u00a345 million (\u20ac49.3 million).\n\nThe 27-year-old Iceland midfielder has put pen to paper on a five-year contract and becomes the Toffees' eighth summer arrival.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\"\n\nSigurdsson said the prospect of working with Everton boss Ronald Koeman was one of the main reasons for switching to Goodison Park.\n\n\"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time,\" Sigurdsson added.\n\n\"Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. He has built up a really good squad here, with strong players, both young and experienced.\n\n\"This was a key factor for me. Ultimately, that is a dream of mine and everyone at this club. I know the supporters and players would agree with that.\"\n\nSigurdsson began his professional career in England with Reading and joined German side Hoffenheim in 2010.\n\nHe moved on loan to Swansea at the start of 2012 and joined Tottenham in a \u00a36.8 million (\u20ac8.65 million) deal six months later, before returning to Swansea in 2014.\n\nSigurdsson, Swansea's player of the year for the past two seasons, has made 50 appearances for Iceland and played a key role in their run to the Euro 2016 quarter-finals.\n\nHis proposed move has dragged on for much of the summer, with Swansea initially valuing their star man at \u00a350 million (\u20ac54.75million).\n\nFinally securing him now, at a slightly lower price, takes Everton's spending since the end of last season to over \u00a3130 million (\u20ac142 million). Sigurdsson follows the likes of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klaassen and Sandro Ramirez as another multi-million-pound acquisition, while the club also secured the free transfer arrival of Wayne Rooney.\n\nSigurdsson, who scored nine goals and provided 13 assists in the league last term, pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest became clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSigurdsson will not feature in Thursday's Europa League play-off against Hajduk Split at Goodison Park, but Koeman indicated he could make his Everton debut in Monday's league clash with Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\n\"He will not be involved tomorrow,\" Koeman said. \"Maybe for Monday, I do not know. I need to talk to him and know what his physical state is. Let's wait to see how the fitness is.\"\n\nKoeman said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley.\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. It looks like a hamstring injury but we need to do more tests . . . to know exactly what the injury is. We need to wait.\"\n\nMidfielder Barkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, appears destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a move to Tottenham, but Koeman said last week there had been no offers for the England international.\n\nKoeman, who has let midfielder Gareth Barry join West Brom, also signalled he would like to strengthen in the current transfer window beyond the capture of Sigurdsson.\n\nHe added on Wednesday: \"Still we are looking in two positions to make the squad even stronger than it is at this These are my targets.\"\n\nSigurdsson becomes Koeman's eighth signing of the summer and the Iceland international revealed the Everton boss was one of the main reasons he wanted to switch to Goodison Park.\n\n\"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time,\" said Sigurdsson. \"Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. He has built up a really good squad here, with strong players, both young and experienced.\n\n\"This was a key factor for me. Ultimately, that is a dream of mine and everyone at this club. I know the supporters and players would agree with that.\"\n\nIn my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League.\n\nRonald Koeman on Gylfi Sigurdsson\n\nEverton have broken the \u00a3100m mark this summer in their transfer spending, and Koeman believes the large sum they have paid for Sigurdsson can help balance the loss of last season's top goalscorer Romelu Lukaku - who joined Manchester United for \u00a390m.\n\nKoeman added: \"In my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League. We have the player here and that's really good for the team.\n\n\"From the beginning, he was one of the key players we wanted to bring to Everton. That's because of his quality, first and foremost, and his experience in the Premier League.\n\n\"We need more productivity. We don't sign one player who will score 25 goals but we need several players around our striker to get that number. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have dipped.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nGSA gives per diem travel rates another bump for 2018\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans -- although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. {"timeCrawl": "12:01:00", "uri": "710295470", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T12:01:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "USA Today", "uri": "usatoday.com", "id": "335"}, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/soccer/2017/08/16/jese-loaned-out-by-psg-looks-to-relaunch-career-at-stoke/104644334/", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3360188", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nSpanish forward Jese will attempt to relaunch his stuttering career in England after leaving Paris Saint-Germain to become the latest Champions League winner at Stoke on Wednesday.\n\nThe 24-year-old Jese joined Stoke on a season-long loan after failing to settle at PSG following his move from Real Madrid for a reported 25 million euros ($29 million) in August 2016. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Spanish team Las Palmas.\n\nStoke, a team from central England that is a perennial mid-table finisher in the Premier League, has become a haven for former high-profile players or one-time prodigies whose careers have dipped.\n\nSince 2014, forwards Bojan Krkic and Ibrahim Afellay have joined from Barcelona while ex-Bayern Munich winger Xherdan Shaqiri has arrived from Inter Milan. They all have Champions League winners' medals, as does ex-Manchester United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who was an offseason signing from West Bromwich Albion.\n\nMost were back-ups for their clubs in their Champions League-winning campaigns, with Jese an unused substitute for Real in its victory over Atletico Madrid in the 2016 final.\n\n\"Jese was a man in demand when PSG made it clear they would allow him to leave on loan and we're delighted he has chosen to join us,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes said. \"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League.\"\n\nJese will play out wide and is viewed as a replacement for Marko Arnautovic, who left Stoke this offseason to join West Ham. Stoke also sold Spanish striker Joselu to Newcastle for an undisclosed fee on Wednesday.\n\nStoke announced the arrival of Jese in a tweet that included audio clips from pundits in the British media saying the club lacked ambition and would struggle in the Premier League this season.\n\nThe team managed by Mark Hughes lost 1-0 at Everton in its opening league game of the season on Saturday.\n\nJese was a highly rated youngster at Real Madrid and made his La Liga debut under coach Jose Mourinho in 2012. He mostly played for Real's reserve team and sustained a serious knee injury in March 2014, ruling him out for nine months.\n\nHe signed a five-year deal with PSG last summer but started only one league game, with another eight appearances as substitute.\n\nAlthough technically skilled, Jese has not played so far this season and does not figure in coach Unai Emery's plans -- although the deal with Stoke does not include an option to buy him. At Las Palmas, Jese scored three goals in 13 games.\n\nJese is Stoke's sixth signing of the summer transfer window.\n\n___\n\nMore AP Premier League coverage: https://apnews.com/tag/PremierLeague\n\n___\n\nSteve Douglas is at www.twitter.com/sdouglas80\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. I'm looking forward to getting to know my team-mates, the city, the training ground, the stadium and all the supporters,\" added Joselu, who spent last season on loan with Deportivo La Coruna.\n\nJoselu, who will compete with Dwight Gayle and Aleksandar Mitrovic for a place up front, is Benitez's sixth summer signing but the former Liverpool manager has expressed his frustration at missing out on other targets such as Arsenal's misfiring Spaniard Lucas Perez.\n\nBenitez, who has clashed with controversial owner Mike Ashley over Newcastle's close season transfer activity, said Joselu could sparkle.\n\n\"We have known Joselu since his days at the Real Madrid academy, and we know that he has the potential to do well for us,\" Benitez told the club website.\n\n\"Obviously he has experience of English football and the Premier League and that was another thing we took into consideration.\n\n\"We think if we can exploit his full potential he will be a good signing for {"timeCrawl": "21:10:00", "uri": "710545572", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:10:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "Breaking News.ie", "uri": "breakingnews.ie", "id": "325"}, "url": "http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/soccer/everton-complete-club-record-signing-of-gylfi-sigurdsson-from-swansea-802364.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Everton have completed the club-record signing of Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea, for a fee believed to be around \u00c2\u00a345million.\n\nThe 27-year-old Iceland midfielder has put pen to paper on a five-year contract and becomes the Toffees' eighth summer arrival.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\"\n\nSigurdsson said the prospect of working with Everton boss Ronald Koeman was one of the main reasons for switching to Goodison Park.\n\n\"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time,\" Sigurdsson added.\n\n\"Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. He has built up a really good squad here, with strong players, both young and experienced.\n\n\"This was a key factor for me. Ultimately, that is a dream of mine and everyone at this club. I know the supporters and players would agree with that.\"\n\nSigurdsson began his professional career in England with Reading and joined German side Hoffenheim in 2010.\n\nHe moved on loan to Swansea at the start of 2012 and joined Tottenham in a \u00c2\u00a36.8million deal six months later, before returning to south Wales in 2014.\n\nSigurdsson, Swansea's player of the year for the past two seasons, has made 50 appearances for Iceland and played a key role in their run to the Euro 2016 quarter-finals.\n\nHis proposed move has dragged on for much of the summer, with Swansea initially valuing their star man at \u00c2\u00a350million.\n\nFinally securing him now, at a slightly lower price, takes Everton's spending since the end of last season to over \u00c2\u00a3130million.\n\nSigurdsson follows the likes of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klaassen and Sandro Ramirez as another multi-million-pound acquisition, while the club also secured the free transfer arrival of Wayne Rooney.\n\nSigurdsson, who scored nine goals and provided 13 assists in the league last term, pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest became clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSigurdsson will not feature in Thursday's Europa League play-off against Hajduk Split at Goodison Park, but Koeman indicated he could make his Everton debut in Monday's league clash with Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\n\"He will not be involved (on Thursday),\" Koeman said. \"Maybe for Monday, I do not know. I need to talk to him and know what his physical state is. Let's wait to see how the fitness is.\"\n\nKoeman said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley.\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. It looks like a hamstring injury but we need to do more tests ... to know exactly what the injury is. We need to wait.\"\n\nMidfielder Barkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, appears destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a move to Tottenham, but Koeman said last week there had been no offers for the England international.\n\nKoeman, who has let midfielder Gareth Barry join West Brom, also signalled he would like to strengthen in the current transfer window beyond the capture of Sigurdsson.\n\nHe added on Wednesday: \"Still we are looking in two positions to make the squad even stronger than it is at this stage.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Hajduk boss Joan Carrillo has acknowledged Everton's strength ahead of Thursday's European clash, but feels there are weaknesses his team can take advantage of.\n\n\"All the games with this team, we play to win,\" Carrillo said at a pre-match press conference.\n\n\"I do not have another method or philosophy.\n\n\"I know Everton have a very good team. They are in the Premier League. And we are talking about signing one player for 50 million euros. But football is 11 against 11.\n\n\"We know the good things of Everton but also the bad things, and we have worked on this.\n\n\"I am an optimist. {"timeCrawl": "09:41:00", "uri": "710231815", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T09:41:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "SuperSport official website", "uri": "supersport.com", "id": "1756"}, "url": "https://www.supersport.com//football/article.aspx?Id=4101364", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363222", "body": "Rafael Benitez's frustration at missing out on several transfer targets abated a little as Spanish striker Joselu on Wednesday agreed a move to Newcastle United from Stoke City.\n\nThe 27-year-old, who scored just four times for Stoke in 27 appearances, cost Newcastle a reported \u00a35 million and signed a three year contract.\n\n\"I feel very happy because I have signed for a very big club,\" he told the club website.\n\n\"I'm very happy to be part of this club, and so excited. I'm looking forward to getting to know my team-mates, the city, the training ground, the stadium and all the supporters,\" added Joselu, who spent last season on loan with Deportivo La Coruna.\n\nJoselu, who will compete with Dwight Gayle and Aleksandar Mitrovic for a place up front, is Benitez's sixth summer signing but the former Liverpool manager has expressed his frustration at missing out on other targets such as Arsenal's misfiring Spaniard Lucas Perez.\n\nBenitez, who has clashed with controversial owner Mike Ashley over Newcastle's close season transfer activity, said Joselu could sparkle.\n\n\"We have known Joselu since his days at the Real Madrid academy, and we know that he has the potential to do well for us,\" Benitez told the club website.\n\n\"Obviously he has experience of English football and the Premier League and that was another thing we took into consideration.\n\n\"We think if we can exploit his full potential he will be a good signing for {"timeCrawl": "14:57:00", "uri": "710948533", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"title": "northwales", "uri": "dailypost.co.uk", "id": "269"}, "url": "http://www.dailypost.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/koeman-sigurdsson-one-best-players-13491187", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nEverton boss Ronald Koeman has no doubt the club have landed one of the Premier League 's best playmakers in Gylfi Sigurdsson.\n\nSigurdsson's switch from Swansea to Everton was completed on Wednesday after the 27-year-old Iceland international passed a medical.\n\nThe deal went through a day after it emerged a deal worth up to \u00a345m for Sigurdsson had been agreed - a record transfer fee paid out by the Merseyside outfit.\n\nWrapping up the signing of a player they have been long pursuing takes Everton's spending since the end of last season beyond \u00a3140m.\n\nKoeman, who had already this summer brought in Jordan Pickford , Michael Keane, Cuco Martina, Davy Klaassen, Sandro Ramirez and Wayne Rooney , said of Sigurdsson on Wednesday: \"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in.\n\n\"We knew we would lose ( Romelu) Lukaku for this season, with that we lost 25 goals, and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team.\n\n\"He is that type of player, with a lot of productivity.\n\n\"He knows the Premier League and he had really good seasons with Swansea. In my opinion he is, in his position, one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nSigurdsson scored nine goals and provided 13 assists in the league last term for Swansea.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\"\n\nKoeman, who has let midfielder Gareth Barry join West Brom , indicated he would still like to strengthen in the current transfer window beyond the capture of Sigurdsson.\n\nSpeaking ahead of Thursday's Europa League qualifying play-off first leg against Hajduk Split at Goodison Park, Koeman said: \"It isn't done. Still we are looking in two positions to make the squad even stronger than it is at this stage.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Koeman said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley .\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. It looks like a hamstring injury but we need to do more tests ... to know exactly what the injury is. We need to wait.\"\n\nThe Dutchman added that there was \"no update\" in terms of the 23-year-old's \"situation\", and when asked if he was in his plans for the coming season, he said: \"I will wait until the end of August.\"\n\nBarkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, has appeared destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a Everton did not reveal the transfer details, saying only that it was a club record. {"timeCrawl": "20:28:00", "uri": "710529722", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:28:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/everton-complete-clubrecord-signing-of-gylfi-sigurdsson-from-swansea-36038614.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36038613.ece/055bd/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-69d0daa2-bd67-464f-ac0d-321810283cb4_I1.jpg\n\nEverton have completed the club-record signing of Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea, for a fee believed to be around \u00a345million.\n\nThe 27-year-old Iceland midfielder has put pen to paper on a five-year contract and becomes the Toffees' eighth summer arrival.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season. \"\n\nSigurdsson said the prospect of working with Everton boss Ronald Koeman was one of the main reasons for switching to Goodison Park.\n\n\"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time,\" Sigurdsson added.\n\n\"Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. He has built up a really good squad here, with strong players, both young and experienced.\n\n\"This was a key factor for me. Ultimately, that is a dream of mine and everyone at this club. I know the supporters and players would agree with that.\"\n\nSigurdsson began his professional career in England with Reading and joined German side Hoffenheim in 2010.\n\nHe moved on loan to Swansea at the start of 2012 and joined Tottenham in a \u00a36.8million deal six months later, before returning to south Wales in 2014.\n\nSigurdsson, Swansea's player of the year for the past two seasons, has made 50 appearances for Iceland and played a key role in their run to the Euro 2016 quarter-finals.\n\nHis proposed move has dragged on for much of the summer, with Swansea initially valuing their star man at \u00a350million.\n\nFinally securing him now, at a slightly lower price, takes Everton's spending since the end of last season to over \u00a3130million.\n\nSigurdsson follows the likes of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klaassen and Sandro Ramirez as another multi-million-pound acquisition, while the club also secured the free transfer arrival of Wayne Rooney.\n\nSigurdsson, who scored nine goals and provided 13 assists in the league last term, pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest became clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSigurdsson will not feature in Thursday's Europa League play-off against Hajduk Split at Goodison Park, but Koeman indicated he could make his Everton debut in Monday's league clash with Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\n\"He will not be involved (on Thursday),\" Koeman said. \"Maybe for Monday, I do not know. I need to talk to him and know what his physical state is. Let's wait to see how the fitness is.\"\n\nKoeman said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley.\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. It looks like a hamstring injury but we need to do more tests ... to know exactly what the injury is. We need to wait.\"\n\nMidfielder Barkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, appears destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a move to Tottenham, but Koeman said last week there had been no offers for the England international.\n\nKoeman, who has let midfielder Gareth Barry join West Brom, also signalled he would like to strengthen in the current transfer window beyond the capture of Sigurdsson.\n\nHe added on Wednesday: \"Still we are looking in two positions to make the squad even stronger than it is at this stage.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Hajduk boss Joan Carrillo has acknowledged Everton's strength ahead of Thursday's European clash, but feels there are weaknesses his team can take advantage of.\n\n\"All the games with this team, we play to win,\" Carrillo said at a pre-match press conference.\n\n\"I do not have another method or philosophy.\n\n\"I know Everton have a very good team. They are in the Premier League. And we are talking about signing one player for 50 million euros. But football is 11 against 11.\n\n\"We know the good things of Everton but also the bad things, and we have worked on this.\n\n\"I am an optimist. These are my targets.\"\n\nSigurdsson becomes Koeman's eighth signing of the summer and the Iceland international revealed the Everton boss was one of the main reasons he wanted to switch to Goodison Park.\n\n\"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time,\" said Sigurdsson. \"Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. {"timeCrawl": "19:53:00", "uri": "710516635", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:53:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"title": "USA Today", "uri": "usatoday.com", "id": "335"}, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/soccer/2017/08/16/everton-signs-iceland-midfielder-sigurdsson-from-swansea/104658976/", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nLIVERPOOL, England (AP) -- Everton has signed Iceland midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea for a club-record fee, further strengthening the team's attacking options to compensate for the departure of striker Romelu Lukaku.\n\nOne of the Premier League's most drawn-out transfers this summer was completed on Wednesday, with the 27-year-old Sigurdsson signing a five-year deal for a transfer fee that British media reported to be 45 million pounds ($58 million). Everton did not reveal the transfer details, saying only that it was a club record. Its previous highest fee was 31.8 million pounds, spent on Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson told Everton's website.\n\nWayne Rooney, Sandro Ramirez and Davy Klaassen are other attacking players to have joined Everton since the end of last season, as part of an outlay of around 135 million pounds ($175 million) on new players. The club recouped 75 million pounds ($97 million) in selling Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\n\"We lost with Lukaku 25 goals and we need more players than one to get that number of goals,\" Everton manager Ronaldo Koeman said. \"He (Sigurdsson) is that type of player. He knows the Premier League. He had really good seasons in Swansea, and he is in my opinion in his position one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nKoeman said Sigurdsson could feature for Everton in its league game at Manchester City on Monday.\n\nSince 2012, when he first moved to the Premier League, no player has scored more goals from direct free kicks than Sigurdsson (seven). He scored nine goals, and set up 13 more, for Swansea last season and scored a total of 30 in three seasons since returning to the Welsh club in 2014.\n\nHe was on loan at Swansea for the second half of the 2011-12 season before playing for Everton from 2012-14.\n\nGoalkeeper Jordan Pickford and defender Michael Keane have also moved to Everton in the offseason as the club looks to improve on its seventh-place finish from last season.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. Reuters\n\nThe former Tottenham player missed Swansea's pre-season tour of the United States while the talks dragged on.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training after Swansea's return from the States, but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nEverton were keen to tie up the swoop before the transfer window closes at the end of August and it is believed Swansea have at last agreed to sell their prize asset.\n\nThe 27-year-old is set to undergo a medical on Wednesday prior to joining Everton for what will be the Merseyside club's record transfer fee.\n\nEverton's previous highest fee was \u00a331 million for Romelu Lukaku, who was sold to Manchester United for a British record \u00a375 million during the close-season.\n\nKoeman has used the Lukaku windfall to fund a spending spree that will surpass \u00a3100 million once Sigurdsson signs.\n\nThe Dutchman re-signed Wayne Rooney from Manchester United, while also bringing in Michael Keane, Jordan Pickford, Davy Klaassen and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nSigurdsson scored nine goals and contributed 13 assists last season as Swansea climbed out of the relegation zone to ensure their survival.\n\nHis arrival may herald the imminent departure of England midfielder Ross Barkley, who has refused to sign a new contract at Everton and is keen to leave, with Tottenham among the clubs interested in his signature.\n\nSwansea boss Paul Clement will use the Sigurdsson cash to strengthen his squad with two or three new signings.\n\nManchester City striker Wilfried Bony, West Brom forward Nacer Chadli and Stoke midfielder Joe Allen have all been linked with Swansea.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 16, 2017 09:52 am | Updated Date: Aug 16, 2017 09:52 am\n\nTags :#Everton#Football#Gylfi Park\n\nEverton have agreed a deal worth up to \u00a345m for Swansea playmaker Gylfi Sigurdsson.\n\nThe Icelandic playmaker will undergo a medical on Wednesday to finally complete his protracted transfer to Goodison Park, it's understood.\n\nThe saga has dragged on for most of the summer with Swansea initially valuing the 27-year-old at \u00a350m.\n\nRead more Saints and Swansea share spoils with stalemate\n\nBut Everton are finally set to secure their number one summer target at a price slightly lower than Swansea had wanted.\n\nSigurdsson pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest had become clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSwansea rejected two Everton bids for Sigurdsson, but Toffees boss Ronald Koeman said last weekend that the deal was \"still close\" after reports that talks between the two clubs had broken down.\n\nAnd Swansea manager Paul Clement was just as keen to close the deal to allow him time to find replacements before the transfer window closes at the end of August.\n\nClement has been keen to remedy the midfielder's future (Getty)\n\n\"The objective and the aim is that at some point the two clubs will meet,\" Clement said ahead of the goalless draw at Southampton.\n\n\"I think the way it's going there needs to be more than likely a compromise on both sides. That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nSigurdsson helped Swansea avoid relegation last season (Getty )\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham's Christian Eriksen, brought more goals and assists to their teams and Everton quickly targeted Sigurdsson as a key signing during a transfer window in which they have spent heavily.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, Jordan Pickford, Davy Klaassen, Michael Keane, Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer Chadli are both on Swansea's radar.\n\nAnd Swansea have also made an enquiry for their former midfielder Joe Allen, although Stoke insist the Wales international is not for sale.\n\nPA\n\nMore about: Gylfi Sigurdsson Swansea City Premier League Everton Reuse content", "id": "9365267", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Gylfi This has taken over six weeks to sort out but the end game is near and Swansea will at least get a huge profit as they bought Sigurdsson for Spurs in 2014 for $11.5 million, but did send Ben Davies and Michel Vorm in the opposite direction. That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City 's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham 's Christian Eriksen, brought more goals and assists to their teams and Everton quickly targeted Sigurdsson as a key signing during a transfer window in which they have spent heavily.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney , Jordan Pickford , Davy Klaassen, Michael Keane, Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer Chadli are both on Swansea's radar.\n\nAnd Swansea have also made an enquiry for their former midfielder Joe Allen , although Stoke insist the Wales international is not for sale.", "id": "9351064", "details": {}, That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham's Christian Eriksen, brought more goals and assists to their teams and Everton quickly targeted Sigurdsson as a key signing during a transfer window in which they have spent heavily.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00c2\u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, Jordan Pickford, Davy Klaassen, Michael Keane, Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer Chadli are both on Swansea's radar.\n\nAnd Swansea have also made an enquiry for their former midfielder Joe Allen, although Stoke insist the Wales international is not for sale.", "id": "9352645", {"timeCrawl": "06:49:00", "uri": "710149745", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T06:49:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"title": "IOL", "uri": "iol.co.za", "id": "1546"}, "url": "https://www.iol.co.za/sport/soccer/premier-league/sigurdsson-poised-to-complete-everton-10813180", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "LIVERPOOL - Everton have agreed a deal worth up to \u00a345m for Swansea playmaker Gylfi Sigurdsson.\n\nThe Icelandic playmaker will undergo a medical on Wednesday to finally complete his protracted transfer to Goodison Park, it's understood.\n\nThe saga has dragged on for most of the summer with Swansea initially valuing the 27-year-old at \u00a350m.\n\nBut Everton are finally set to secure their number one summer target at a price slightly lower than Swansea had wanted.\n\nSigurdsson pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest had become clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSwansea rejected two Everton bids for Sigurdsson, but Toffees boss Ronald Koeman said last weekend that the deal was \"still close\" after reports that talks between the two clubs had broken down.\n\nAnd Swansea manager Paul Clement was just as keen to close the deal to allow him time to find replacements before the transfer window closes at the end of August.\n\n\"The objective and the aim is that at some point the two clubs will meet,\" Clement said ahead of the goalless draw at Southampton.\n\n\"I think the way it's going there needs to be more than likely a compromise on both sides. That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham's Christian Eriksen, brought more goals and assists to their teams and Everton quickly targeted Sigurdsson as a key signing during a transfer window in which they have spent heavily.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, Jordan Pickford, Davy Klaassen, Michael Keane, Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer Chadli are both on Swansea's radar.\n\nAnd Swansea have also made an enquiry for their former midfielder Joe Allen, although Stoke insist the Wales international is not for sale.\n\nThe Reuters picLONDON, Aug 16 -- Iceland midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson is due to complete a \u00a345 million (RM248.7 million) move to Everton from Premier League rivals Swansea City later today after he passed a medical, Everton manager Ronaldo Koeman announced.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five-year contract worth \u00a3100,000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8 million they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"I have seen the doctor and there is no problem,\" said Koeman at a press conference on the eve of their Europa League match with Hakjduk Split.\n\n\"Still he needs to sign, but I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350 million.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340 million offer from 2016 champions Leicester City at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, though, that Everton will get their way in paying an initial \u00a340 million with another \u00a35 million to follow, taking their summer spending under Koeman to over \u00a3140 million.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100 million so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330m), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6m), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330m), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375 million sale of Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\nThey could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is presently injured and likely to be out until October.\n\nKoeman was not very forthcoming when asked about Barkley's situation and his long-term future at the club.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" said Koeman.\n\n\"It looks like a hamstring injury but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\n\n\"I will wait until the end of August,\" he added when asked about Barkley's future at the club.\n\nIcelandic international Sigurdsson finished third in combined goals and assists amongst midfielders in the Premier League last "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36037457.ece/820c5/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-799ee268-2d7b-4837-9dda-c28a6f532cd2_I1.jpg\n\nSwansea midfielder Gylfi transfer to Goodison Park, Press Association Sport understands.\n\nThe saga has dragged on for most of the summer with Swansea initially valuing the 27-year-old at \u00a350million.\n\nBut Everton are finally set to secure their number one summer target at a price slightly lower than Swansea had wanted and take their summer spending to over \u00a3140million.\n\nSigurdsson pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest had become clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSwansea rejected two Everton bids for Sigurdsson, but Toffees boss Ronald Koeman said last weekend that the deal was \"still close\" after reports that talks between the two clubs had broken down.\n\nAnd Swansea manager Paul Clement was just as keen to close the deal to allow him time to find replacements before the transfer window closes at the end of August.\n\n\"The objective and the aim is that at some point the two clubs will meet,\" Clement said ahead of the goalless draw at Southampton.\n\n\"I think the way it's going there needs to be more than likely a compromise on both sides. That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham's Christian Eriksen, brought more goals and assists to their teams and Everton quickly targeted Sigurdsson as a key signing during a transfer window in which they have spent heavily.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, Jordan Pickford, Davy Klaassen, Michael Keane, Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer Chadli are both on Swansea's radar.\n\nAnd Swansea have also made an enquiry for their former midfielder Joe Allen, although Stoke insist the Wales international is not for sale.", "id": "9431327", "Iceland midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson is due to complete a \u00a345 million ($58m, 49.4m euros) move to Everton from Premier League rivals Swansea City later on Wednesday after he passed a medical, Everton manager Ronald Koeman announced.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five-year contract worth \u00a3100,000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8 million they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"I have seen the doctor and there is no problem,\" said Koeman at a press conference on the eve of their Europa League match with Hakjduk Split.\n\n\"Still he needs to sign, but I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350 million.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340 million offer from 2016 champions Leicester City at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, though, that Everton will get their way in paying an initial \u00a340 million with another \u00a35 million to follow, taking their summer spending under Koeman to over \u00a3140 million.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100 million so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford \u00a375 million sale of Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\n\"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in,\" Koeman said.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season, with that we lost 25 goals, and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team.\n\n\"He is that type of player, with a lot of productivity.\"\n\nEverton could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is currently injured and likely to be out until October.\n\nKoeman was not very forthcoming when asked about Barkley's situation and his long-term future at the club.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" said Koeman.\n\n\"It looks like a hamstring injury but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\n\n\"I will wait until the end of August,\" he added when asked about Barkley's future at the club.\n\nIcelandic international Sigurdsson {"timeCrawl": "18:57:00", "uri": "710494147", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:57:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4795586/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Everton have completed the signing of Swansea midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson for a club-record \u00a345million after he completed his medical on Wednesday.\n\nThe Iceland international has signed a five-year deal at Goodison Park worth \u00a3100,000 a week, ending one of the summer's most protracted transfer sagas. Ronald Koeman's side will pay an initial fee of \u00a340m and two \u00a32.5m add-ons.\n\nSigurdsson's arrival on Merseyside means Koeman's side has now spent \u00a3144m this summer, as the club look to challenge for a Champions League place in the Dutchman's second season.\n\nEverton have completed the signing of Gylfi Sigurdsson for a club-record \u00a345million\n\n\u1f440 | Look who's here... pic.twitter.com/iAcnN5SSn4 -- Everton (@Everton)\n\nAugust 16, 2017\n\nAfter completing his move, he said: 'Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club.\n\n'This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\n\n'For myself, I would like to score as many goals as possible and create as many goals for my team-mates as I can. These are my targets.\n\n'But it is always the same thing: as long as the team is winning I will be more than happy.'\n\nSigurdsson has been named Swansea's player of the year in each of the previous two seasons\n\nSix of Everton's top seven biggest ever transfer fees have now been paid by Farhad Moshiri\n\nLeicester City also made a \u00a340m offer but Sigurdsson had his heart set on a move to Goodison.\n\nHe refused to travel to the USA for Swansea's pre-season tour and missed their friendly with Birmingham after declaring he was not in the right frame of mind.\n\nSigurdsson scored nine goals and created 13 more last season, and has been named Swansea's player of the year in each of the previous two seasons.\n\nIndeed, he swept the board last campaign winning players' player of the year for the second season running, supporters' player of the year and away supporters' player of the year.\n\nThough Swansea had publicly declared they wanted \u00a350million for him, discussions had centred around the \u00a340m mark with two proposals rejected before Tuesday's breakthrough.\n\nThe Iceland midfielder will undergo a medical on Wednesday at the Merseyside club\n\nSigurdsson replaces Romelu Lukaku as Everton's record signing following his move in 2014\n\nSigurdsson - who covered more ground than any other Premier League player last season (433km) - is expected to be unveiled to the Goodison crowd ahead of Thursday's Europa League tie with Hajduk Split.\n\nThe former Tottenham midfielder has not played a match of any description since he captained Swansea in a friendly defeat at Barnet on 12 July, so it will take some time for the player to gain match fitness.\n\nSigurdsson has maintained a dignified silence during the lengthy transfer negotiations between the two clubs but he is now finally Everton's record signing, beating the \u00a331.8m they paid Chelsea for striker Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\nThey have enjoyed a productive transfer window, re-signing Wayne Rooney from Manchester United and spending a potential \u00a330m each on centre back Michael Keane and goalkeeper Jordan Pickford.\n\nMidfielder Davy Klaassen also arrived from Ajax for \u00a323.6m and striker Sandro Ramirez from Malaga for \u00a35.2m.\n\nEverton midfielder Ross Barkley is facing the prospect of six weeks out with a torn hamstring\n\nThe player is widely expected to leave Goodison Park this summer, with Tottenham interested\n\nPREMIER LEAGUE'S MOST CREATIVE MIDFIELDERS SINCE 2014-15 SEASON Rank Player Goals Assists Goals + Assists 1 Christian Eriksen 24 32 56 2 Gylfi Sigurdsson 27 26 53 3 Eden Hazard 34 17 51 3 Mesut Ozil 18 33 51 5 Cesc Fabregas 13 37 50 6 Sadio Mane 35 14 49 7 Riyad Mahrez 27 18 45 = Dele Alli 29 16 45 9 David Silva 18 26 44 10 Philippe Coutinho 26 17 43 11 Kevin De Bruyne 13 27 40 12 Dusan Tadic 14 24 38 13 Ross Barkley 15 18 33\n\nSigurdsson's arrival could hasten the departure of Ross Barkley, who has refused to sign a new contract with his boyhood club.\n\nThe England midfielder has been linked with a move to Tottenham but Everton are yet to receive an official offer and his exit has been complicated after scans revealed he tore a hamstring in training.\n\nBarkley is facing six weeks out with a Grade Three tear which could put paid to hopes of a move away this summer. But Everton can look forward to a more creative midfielder.\n\nSigurdsson has either scored or assisted 53 goals since the start of the 2014-15 season. Only Tottenham's Christian Eriksen boasts a high number in that time, with Barkley having been involved in 20 fewer goals than the Icelandic.\n\nEVERTON'S BUSY SUMMER TRANSFER WINDOW\n\nGylfi Sigurdsson has completed a \u00a345million move from Swansea to Everton - a deal that has added to what has been a considerably busy summer for the Toffees in terms of recruitment.\n\nHere, Sportsmail look at the significant signings manager Ronald Koeman has made - other than Sigurdsson - to reshape his squad since the end of last season.\n\nJORDAN PICKFORD\n\nPickford joined from Sunderland in June for an initial \u00a325million which could rise to \u00a330million with add-ons, a record fee for a British goalkeeper. Koeman will hope the 23-year-old solves the problem of inconsistent goalkeeping which dogged the Toffees last season.\n\nMICHAEL KEANE\n\nKoeman needed to freshen up an ageing defence and 24-year-old England centre-back Keane, signed from Burnley for a fee which could also rise to \u00a330million, was identified as the long-term leader at the back, with Ashley Williams and club captain Phil Jagielka turning 33 and 35 respectively in August.\n\nCUCO MARTINA\n\nAnother boost for Everton in terms of defensive options. Martina had been signed by Koeman for Southampton in 2015 and the Curacao right-back reunited with his old boss this summer following the expiry of his contract with the Saints.\n\nDAVY KLAASSEN\n\nThe Holland midfielder, previously Ajax captain, was brought in for \u00a323.5million to provide more creativity and goals from midfield, being touted as a replacement for Ross Barkley, whose future at Everton remains in doubt.\n\nSANDRO RAMIREZ\n\nThe former Barcelona striker was signed from Malaga after Everton triggered his release clause in July. Fourteen goals in LaLiga last season indicates he should add more firepower to a side who were heavily reliant on the now-departed Romelu Lukaku.\n\nWAYNE ROONEY\n\nRooney made an emotional return to his boyhood club in July, rejoining from Manchester United for an undisclosed fee 13 years after going the other way.\n\nThere will be great interest in how the 31-year-old, United and England's record goalscorer, fares back at his old side - and scoring the winner on Saturday in his first Premier League match since the move certainly made for a good start.", "id": "9546212", "details": {},
