{"timeCrawl": "19:41:00", "uri": "709946074", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T19:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/gylfi-sigurdsson-poised-to-complete-everton-move-36034593.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36034592.ece/84147/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-0faeac65-1c16-464d-83b6-1ff3dbb9f196_I1.jpg\n\nEverton have agreed a deal worth up to \u00a345million for Swansea playmaker Gylfi Sigurdsson.\n\nThe Icelandic playmaker will undergo a medical on Wednesday to finally complete his protracted transfer to Goodison Park, Press Association Sport understands.\n\nThe saga has dragged on for most of the summer with Swansea initially valuing the 27-year-old at \u00a350million.\n\nBut Everton are finally set to secure their number one summer target at a price slightly lower than Swansea had wanted.\n\nSigurdsson pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest had become clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSwansea rejected two Everton bids for Sigurdsson, but Toffees boss Ronald Koeman said last weekend that the deal was \"still close\" after reports that talks between the two clubs had broken down.\n\nAnd Swansea manager Paul Clement was just as keen to close the deal to allow him time to find replacements before the transfer window closes at the end of August.\n\n\"The objective and the aim is that at some point the two clubs will meet,\" Clement said ahead of the goalless draw at Southampton.\n\n\"I think the way it's going there needs to be more than likely a compromise on both sides. That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer {"timeCrawl": "15:41:00", "uri": "710969461", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"title": "WalesOnline", "uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "id": "1272"}, "url": "http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-fans-should-absolutely-thrilled-13488996", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Get rugby updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nThe long-drawn saga finally came to an end on Wednesday night as Everton confirmed the signing of Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea City.\n\nFive long weeks had passed from when Sigurdsson informed the Swans that he was not in the right frame of mind to travel on their pre-season tour of America to when he officially put pen to paper on a five-year deal with the Toffees.\n\nHe missed Swansea's last five pre-season outings having most recently featured for his former club against Barnet and was also absent for the Premier League opener against Southampton at St Mary's Stadium.\n\nBut despite his lack of match action, Everton manager Ronald Koeman has stated that his new man could make his debut as early as Monday when the Toffees face Pep Guardiola's Man City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\nWhile Everton are blessed with midfield options at the moment, the \u00a345m capture of Sigurdsson has certainly whetted the appetite on the blue half of Merseyside.\n\nThe departure of star striker Romelu Lukaku to Manchester United meant the Blues would be significantly lacking in the goal department this term.\n\nAnd Koeman was quick to address that problem by recruiting the likes of Sandro Ramirez from Malaga and Davy Klaassen from Ajax, as well as securing a deal to take Wayne Rooney back to his boyhood club from Lukaku's new side Manchester United.\n\nLukaku netted a stunning 25 goals in the league for the Toffees last term, but worryingly, their next best contributor was Ross Barkley who found the back of the net on just five occasions in the Premier League.\n\nAnd when you consider that Koeman has already stated Barkley could leave his home club in the near future - with Tottenham thought to be interested in the currently injured England international - there's no doubt the Toffees were in desperate need of more creativity ahead of the 2017-18 campaign, and as Koeman has repeatedly stressed, more productivity.\n\nWhile Rooney - who scored on his return to Goodison Park in the Toffees' league opener against Stoke - can lead the line, it appears Koeman is eager to deploy England's record scorer in the No.10 role.\n\nAnd with young Dominic Calvert-Lewin being the only other out-and-out striker in the Everton squad to challenge Spaniard Sandro Ramirez, the Blues are still somewhat light up top, something Koeman is eager to address before the end of the summer transfer window.\n\n\"We've worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in,\" said Koeman on Wednesday.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team.\n\n\"We lost by Lukaku 25 goals and we need more players than one to get that number of goals and he's that type of player. He (Sigurdsson) knows the Premier League and he had a few really good seasons at Swansea and in my opinion, in the Premier League he's one of the best in his position.\"\n\nSo it's clear to see Koeman wants more from his midfield men this season. A lot more.\n\nThe Blues have a wealth of midfield options in addition to their new recruits, with the likes of Morgan Schneiderlin, Idrissa Gueye and 19-year-old Tom Davies all impressing last term.\n\nBut with combined transfer fees of around \u00a370m, there will be huge pressure on Klaassen and Sigurdsson - more so the latter who is now the Toffees' record signing - to deliver the goods in their debut seasons on Merseyside.\n\nNot that Sigurdsson will be phased by that.\n\nAfter all, he helped guide Iceland into the quarter-finals of Euro 2016, and in the following season scored 10 goals in all competitions as well as registering 13 Premier League assists to drag the Swans to safety under Paul Clement.\n\nAnd those who have watched from the stands of the Liberty with the number 23 stamped on the back of their now probably discarded shirts will tell you, Sigurdsson is far more than a one-season wonder. He did the business in every campaign for the Swans.\n\nIn the last three Premier League seasons, Sigurdsson scored more free-kick goals (six) than any other player and was involved in 53 goals, with Christian Eriksen (54) being the only midfielder to better his tally over that period.\n\nHe has also chalked up 26 assists in England's top flight, with Cesc Fabregas, Mesut Ozil, Christian Eriksen and Kevin de Bruyne being the only other midfielders to achieve more.\n\nAnd when it comes to hitting the back of the net, Sigurdsson has averaged nine goals a season in the league since signing a permanent deal with Swansea in 2014, equal with Leicester man Riyad Mahrez while Tottenham's Dele Alli is the only midfield man to have managed more (28).\n\nIt's all music to the ears of the Everton faithful, and puts a huge tick in the productivity and creativity boxes on Koeman's wish list.\n\nOn top of all of those impressive stats, Sigurdsson also clocked up 433 kilometres (269 miles) in the Premier League last season, more than any other player, something that will be hugely pleasing for Koeman and Everton's fitness coach Jan Kluitenberg.\n\nAre there any concerns? Following his less successful spell at Tottenham, perhaps there are a few minor worries.\n\nBut while it didn't work as Sigurdsson would have hoped with Spurs, Mauricio Pochettino admitted his regret in allowing the \"perfect\" Iceman to leave White Hart Lane to sign a permanent deal with the Swans after having a loan spell with the club two years earlier.\n\nSo as far as the future is concerned, it's been some time since there was so much excitement at Everton given that they have splashed the cash this summer while a move to a new stadium on Bramley Moore Dock is also on the horizon.\n\nAnd in Sigurdsson, the Swansea faithful will testify that Everton have a real gem on their hands, and crucially, a player that can help take them to the next level under Koeman.", "id": "9723693", false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "LONDON: Iceland midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson is due to complete a \u00a345 million (US$58 million) move to Everton from Premier League rivals Swansea City later on Wednesday (Aug 16) after he passed a medical, Everton manager Ronald Koeman announced.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five-year contract worth \u00a3100,000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8 million they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"I have seen the doctor and there is no problem,\" said Koeman at a press conference on the eve of their Europa League match with Hakjduk Split. \"Still he needs to sign, but I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350 million.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340 million offer from 2016 champions Leicester City at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, though, that Everton will get their way in paying an initial \u00a340 million with another \u00a35 million to follow, taking their summer spending under Koeman to over \u00a3140 million.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100 million so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330 million), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6 million), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330 million), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375 million sale of Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\n\"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in,\" Koeman said.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season, with that we lost 25 goals, and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team. He is that type of player, with a lot of productivity.\"\n\nEverton could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is currently injured and likely to be out until October.\n\nKoeman was not very forthcoming when asked about Barkley's situation and his long-term future at the club.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" said Koeman. \"It looks like a hamstring injury but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\n\n\"I will wait until the end of August,\" he added when asked about Barkley's future at the club.\n\nIcelandic international Sigurdsson finished third in combined goals and assists amongst midfielders in the Premier League last season behind Manchester City's Kevin De has completed his move from Swansea to Everton\n\nAnd the Everton boss finally got his wish last night as the Toffees confirmed the club record \u00a345m signing of the Iceland ace from Swansea on a five-year deal.\n\nNow the pressure will be on Koeman for Sigurdsson to deliver after Everton took their summer spending to \u00a3150m.\n\nSigurdsson, 27, passed a medical yesterday morning and was \"in the blue\" of Everton according to his new boss.\n\nFormer Saints boss Koeman had been craving to work with the Iceland international as he believes the midfielder's creativity can unlock the best of Premier League defences.\n\nIt is why last summer when Farhad Moshiri's ambition lured him to become manager at Goodison Park, Sigurdsson was one of the top names on Koeman's wanted list.\n\nHe tried and failed to sign him in January, as Swansea were not ready to part with him until this summer and even then it has been a saga.\n\nKoeman has never wavered in his belief that Sigurdsson is the man to create and score goals for a side who heavily relied on the now departed Romelu Lukaku last season when the Belgian scored 25 times.\n\nAnd he requested chairman Bill Kenwright and major investor Moshiri to dig deep to get the deal over the line despite Swansea driving a hard bargain.\n\n\"Of course it's always about signings and spending money and with that comes more pressure,\" said Koeman.\n\nPremier League clubs ranked by their record attendance WHICH Premier League club has the highest record attendance? 1 / 20 GETTY 20. Bournemouth - 28,799 (v Man Utd, Dean Court, March 1957)\n\n\"In my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League\"\n\nEverton boss Ronald Koeman\n\n\"We tried when I was at Southampton to sign Sigurdsson but we did not have that finance possibility that we have now in Everton.\n\n\"I'm really happy because the board and especially our chairman, Bill Kenwright, did everything to get him. It took some time but finally we have signed the player.\n\n\"In my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League. We have the player here and that's really good for the team.\n\n\"From the beginning, he was one of the key players we wanted to bring to Everton. That's because of his quality, first and foremost, and his experience in the Premier League.\n\n\"We need more productivity. We don't sign one player who will score 25 goals but we need several players around our striker to get that number.\n\n\"He is one of those productive players which he has shown at Swansea and also in the past.\n\n\"He can play in different positions. hamstring injury.\n\nHe will not be the last recruit for Everton this summer as Koeman wants another striker and a left-footed centre-back before the window closes on August 31.\n\nSigning a No 9 though is proving difficult after the Toffees admitted defeat in trying to lure Olivier Giroud from Arsenal.\n\nKoeman is open to bringing in a loan recruit as he expects the striker hunt to go on That is very often how a deal is made.\n\n\"We are at a critical stage of this situation and hope it's going to be resolved very quickly.\"\n\nSigurdsson's importance to Swansea was underlined by the fact he scored nine league goals and had 13 assists as the club just avoided relegation from the Premier League last season.\n\nOnly two other players, Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham's Christian Eriksen, brought more goals and assists to their teams and Everton quickly targeted Sigurdsson as a key signing during a transfer window in which they have spent heavily.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, Jordan Pickford, Davy Klaassen, Michael Keane, Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nBut that figure will now significantly rise with the capture of Sigurdsson, who can fill a variety of forward positions.\n\nSwansea hope to use the Sigurdsson cash by strengthening their squad with two or three players before the window closes.\n\nWilfried Bony, their former striker who appears surplus to requirements at Manchester City, and West Brom forward Nacer Chadli are both on Swansea's radar.\n\nAnd Swansea have also made an enquiry for their former midfielder Joe Allen, although Stoke insist the Wales international is not for sale.\n\nSwansea striker Fernando Llorente, meanwhile, will miss Manchester United's Premier League visit on Saturday.\n\nLlorente returned to training on Tuesday after fracturing his arm on a cycling holiday but will not be considered for the United game.\n\n\"Because of the nature of the injury to the arm, he lost a lot of upper-body bulk,\" Clement said.\n\n\"We will take it day by day with him. Everton from Premier League rivals Swansea City later on Wednesday after he passed a medical, Everton manager Ronaldo Koeman announced.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five-year contract worth \u00a3100,000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8 million they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"I have seen the doctor and there is no problem,\" said Koeman at a press conference on the eve of their Europa League match with Hakjduk Split.\n\n\"Still he needs to sign, but I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350 million.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340 million offer from 2016 champions Leicester City at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, though, that Everton will get their way in paying an initial \u00a340 million with another \u00a35 million to follow, taking their summer spending under Koeman to over \u00a3140 million.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100 million so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330m), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6m), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330m), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375 million sale of Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\nThey could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is presently injured and likely to be out until October.\n\nKoeman was not very forthcoming when asked about Barkley's situation and his long-term future at the club.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" said Koeman.\n\n\"It looks like a hamstring injury but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\n\n\"I will wait until the end of August,\" he added when asked about Barkley's future at the club.\n\nIcelandic international Sigurdsson finished third in combined from PSG and has been brought in to replace the volatile Austrian who left the club last month after submitting a former transfer request.\n\nArnautovic's departure was far from amicable, though, with the forward publicly accusing his old club of a lack of ambition\n\n\"I wanted to join West Ham because for me it's a bigger, more ambitious club,\" he said upon arrival at the London Stadium.\n\nBut bigger, more ambitious club than Stoke\", the Potters' social media account went on to define the word 'ambition' before detailing Jese's past clubs and honours, which include two Champions League titles.\n\nThe Spaniard follows Darren Fletcher, Kurt Zouma, Maxim Choupa-Moting, Bruno Martins Indi and Josh Tymon in checking-in at the bet365 Stadium this summer.\n\nHe spent nine seasons with Real Madrid, scoring 12 goals in 62 La Liga appearances, and was part of their Champions League winning squads in 2014 and 2016.\n\nHis progress was disrupted by a serious knee injury but last summer he {"timeCrawl": "09:05:00", "uri": "710214768", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T09:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4795104/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3360188", "body": "Sportsmail's PETE JENSON reflects on how he has ended up in the Potteries\n\nJese Rodriguez is one of the best strikers to come out of Real Madrid's youth academy since Raul.\n\nIf he doesn't want that to be the extent of his footballing achievements he needs to turn the corner in a career that has been drifting for the last two years.\n\nMark Hughes and Stoke might be just the combination that saves him.\n\nStoke have signed winger Jese Rodriguez on a season-long loan from Paris-Saint Germain\n\nAs a Real Madrid academy product, he won La Liga, Copa del Rey and two Champions Leagues\n\nJese, pictured with his girlfriend Aurah Ruiz, has recently become a father for the third time\n\nSo this time last year wasn't Jes\u00e9 the Neymar of his day?\n\nPSG paid \u20ac21m (around \u00a319m) for him last August and the Parisians were very excited about the prospect of a former Real Madrid player joining them. Little did they know they would come 12 months later.\n\nAnd he didn't really deliver?\n\nHis presentation went well enough. His girlfriend Aurah Ruiz took centre-stage at the Parc des Princes unveiling.\n\nThe images of the couple, along with the video of the rap single 'Yo Sabia' that he had recorded under the alias Jey M made the headlines, but when the glitz and the glamour faded the goals never came in the first half of a very disappointing season.\n\nRuiz is frequently seen on Jese Instagrmam and she took centre-stage at the Parc des Princes\n\nAll his own fault or mitigating circumstances?\n\nPSG boss Unai Emery can be a difficult coach to get along with and he had his own problems adjusting to life in Ligue 1.\n\nThere was early friction between the two with the player feeling that as the big summer signing he should have been treated a little better.\n\nIf being giving a star-spangled welcome in Paris swelled his ego he will have been humbled by the subsequent loan move to Spanish mid-table side Las Palmas, so he will perhaps arrive a more level-headed individual at Stoke.\n\nJese will now test his qualities in the Premier League with a loan deal at Stoke City\n\nWhat happened at Las Palmas?\n\nHe was returning to his boyhood club. There was an over-eagerness to please on the pitch at the start and he had to endure a disastrous debut missing an open goal in the defeat to lowly Granada by actually turning a perfect cross away from goal instead of passing it into an empty net.\n\nThings improved, but not by much and he finished up with three goals in 16 games. Las Palmas were never going to have the money to keep him on loan for another season anyway.\n\nThe 24-year-old failed to make the grade at Real under Zinedine Zidane but he is still ambitious\n\nAnother bad move then?\n\nLas Palmas don't aspire to much more than mid-table safety and the club had already obtained that before he played his first game. Coach Quique Seti\u00e9n didn't really want another forward. He felt it was the defence that needed sorting out. He was also in a contract dispute with the club and poised to leave. All in all it wasn't the greatest environment for Jese to get back to his best.\n\nThe Spaniard has spent just one season at the French club following his Real Madrid exit\n\nWhen he was at his best, just how good was he?\n\nHe shone for Spain right from under-16 level, going on to win the Under-19 European Championship in 2012 finishing as top scorer. He was outstanding in Real Madrid's youth team too, first coming through as a winger but then scoring a record 22 goals for the B-team at a time when they were playing in Spain's highly competitive second division.\n\nDespite having Cristiano Ronaldo, Karim Benzema, James Rodriguez and Gareth Bale ahead of him in the first team he managed, against all the odds, to break through under Carlo Ancelotti in 2013-14. There were even calls for his inclusion in Vicente del Bosque's Spain squad for the 2014 World Cup.\n\nJese broke through at Real under Carlo Ancelotti but he soon found himself out of favour\n\nWhat went wrong?\n\nOn February 18, 2014, in the last-16 Champions League game against Schalke he tore cruciate ligaments in his right knee and had to kiss goodbye his World Cup dream and eight months of football. If he debuts on Saturday he will come up against the player involved in his awful injury, Arsenal's new signing Sead Kolasinac.\n\nTerrible injury, terrible timing\n\nHe was out for 258 days but his head never dropped and he was welcomed back by a Real Madrid dressing room who had nicknamed him 'Bichito' a diminutive version of 'Bicho' Ronaldo's moniker meaning 'bug' but suggesting something more along the lines of 'force of nature'.\n\nHe showed he had got over the injury when Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane picked him for a Champions League game against Roma in the Olympic Stadium. He scored and gave full-back Lucas Digne (now of Barcelona), a torrid time.\n\nBut the competition was tougher than ever at Madrid and PSG seemed like a good idea when they came calling last year.\n\nJese is likely to fill the void left by Marko Arnautovic as part of a three-pronged attack at Stoke\n\nWhere will he play for Stoke? And what should we call him?\n\nIn a three-pronged attack he would play as a wide forward. And because Rodriguez is as common as Smith in Spain he has always answered to Jes\u00e9. That's Jesay no Jessie. Stoke supporters will come up with something.\n\nOverall should they be positive?\n\nHe's got genuine talent and with Mark Hughes coaching him he can become a much more complete forward. The Stoke fans will no doubt get behind him and stick with him in a way that he will not have experienced in France or Spain. It's easy to dismiss him as an airhead busy wasting his talent.\n\nBut behind the rap videos and glamorous girlfriend he has shown that as well as being a character, he does also have character. If he came back from a career threatening injury then he can come back from some bad career choices.\n\nAnd if he concentrates solely on his football then linking up with Hughes could be the making of him. If thing go well we could see Peter Crouch in Jes\u00e9's next video.\n\nJese is a character who will bring a new dimension to a physical Stoke side this coming term", "id": "9439743", "details": {}, "eng-3364130", "body": "LONDON - Iceland midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson is due to complete a \u00a345 million move to Everton from Premier League rivals Swansea City later on Wednesday after he passed a medical, Everton manager Ronaldo Koeman announced.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five-year contract worth \u00a3100 000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8 million they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"I have seen the doctor and there is no problem,\" said Koeman at a press conference on the eve of their Europa League match with Hakjduk Split.\n\n\"Still he needs to sign, but I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350m.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340m offer from 2016 champions Leicester City at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, though, that Everton will get their way in paying an initial \u00a340m with another \u00a35m to follow, taking their summer spending under Koeman to over \u00a3140m.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330m), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6m), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330m), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375m sale of Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\nThey could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is presently injured and likely to be out until October.\n\nKoeman was not very forthcoming when asked about Barkley's situation and his long-term future at the club.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" said Koeman.\n\n\"It looks like a hamstring injury, but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\n\n\"I will wait until the end of August,\" he added when asked about Barkley's future at the club.\n\nIcelandic international Sigurdsson finished third in combined goals and assists amongst midfielders in the Premier League last season behind Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne and Tottenham's Koeman announced.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five-year contract worth \u00a3100,000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8 million they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\n\"I have seen the doctor and there is no problem,\" said Koeman at a press conference on the eve of their Europa League match with Hakjduk Split.\n\n\"Still he needs to sign, but I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the million.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100 million so far in recruiting former favorite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330m), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6m), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330m), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375 million sale of Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\nThey could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is presently injured and likely to be out until October.\n\nKoeman was not very forthcoming when asked about Barkley's situation and his long-term future at the club. \"He stopped training last Monday,\" said Koeman.\n\n\"It looks like a hamstring injury but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\n\n\"I will wait until the end of August,\" he added when asked about Barkley's future at the But I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson's proposed move has dragged on for much of the summer, with Swansea initially valuing their star man at \u00c2\u00a350m.\n\nFinally securing him now, at a slightly lower price, is set to take Everton's spending since the end of last season to over \u00c2\u00a3140m.\n\nKoeman, who has already this summer brought in the likes of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klaassen, Sandro Ramirez and Wayne Rooney, said of Sigurdsson: \"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season, with that we lost 25 goals, and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team.\n\n\"He is that type of player, with a lot of productivity.\n\n\"He knows the Premier League and he had really good seasons with Swansea. In my opinion he is, in his position, one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nSigurdsson, who scored nine goals and provided 13 assists in the league last term, pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest became clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSigurdsson will not feature in Thursday's contest at Goodison Park, but Koeman has indicated he could make his Everton debut in Monday's league clash with Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\n\"He will not be involved tomorrow,\" Koeman said.\n\n\"Maybe for Monday, I do not know. I need to talk to him and know what his physical state is. Let's wait to see how the fitness is.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Koeman has said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley.\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. It looks like a hamstring injury but we need to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is. We need to wait.\"\n\nThe Dutchman added that there was \"no update\" in terms of the 23-year-old's \"situation\", and when asked if he was in his plans for the coming season, he said: \"I will wait until the end of August.\"\n\nBarkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, appears destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a move Reuters\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350 million.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340 million offer one from 2016 champions Leicester at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, though, that Everton will get their way in paying an initial \u00a340 million with another \u00a35 million to follow, taking their close season spending under Ronald Koeman to over \u00a3140 million.\n\nEverton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100 million so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330 million), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6 million), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330 million), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375 million sale of striker Romelu Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\nThey could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is presently injured and likely to be out till October.\n\nIcelandic international Sigurdsson finished third in combined goals and assists amongst midfielders in the Premier League last {"timeCrawl": "15:33:00", "uri": "710401006", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T15:33:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/gylfi-sigurdsson-close-to-signing-for-everton-ronald-koeman-36038614.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36038613.ece/055bd/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-69d0daa2-bd67-464f-ac0d-321810283cb4_I1.jpg\n\nGylfi Sigurdsson's switch from Swansea to Everton edged closer to completion on Wednesday as Toffees boss Ronald Koeman confirmed the midfielder had passed his medical.\n\nIt emerged on Tuesday night that a deal worth up to \u00a345million for Sigurdsson had been agreed, which would be a record transfer fee paid out by the Merseyside club.\n\nSpeaking at a press conference to preview Thursday's Europa League qualifying play-off first leg against Hajduk Split, Koeman made it clear Everton's recruitment of the 27-year-old Iceland international was all but finalised.\n\n\"The latest is that he had his medical this morning and what I heard from the doctor was that there was no problem with that,\" Koeman said.\n\n\"I don't know if still he needs to sign. But I saw him in the blue!\"\n\nSigurdsson's proposed move has dragged on for much of the summer, with Swansea initially valuing their star man at \u00a350m.\n\nFinally securing him now, at a slightly lower price, is set to take Everton's spending since the end of last season to over \u00a3140m.\n\nKoeman, who has already this summer brought in the likes of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klaassen, Sandro Ramirez and Wayne Rooney, said of Sigurdsson: \"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season, with that we lost 25 goals, and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team.\n\n\"He is that type of player, with a lot of productivity.\n\n\"He knows the Premier League and he had really good seasons with Swansea. In my opinion he is, in his position, one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nSigurdsson, who scored nine goals and provided 13 assists in the league last term, pulled out of Swansea's pre-season tour to the United States after Everton's interest became clear.\n\nHe rejoined first-team training upon Swansea's return from the States but he did not figure in their Premier League opener at Southampton on Saturday.\n\nSigurdsson will not feature in Thursday's contest at Goodison Park, but Koeman has indicated he could make his Everton debut in Monday's league clash with Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\n\"He will not be involved tomorrow,\" Koeman said.\n\n\"Maybe for Monday, I do not know. I need to talk to him and know what his physical state is. Let's wait to see how the fitness is.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Koeman has said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley.\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. It looks like a hamstring injury but we need to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is. We need to wait.\"\n\nThe Dutchman added that there was \"no update\" in terms of the 23-year-old's \"situation\", and when asked if he was in his plans for the coming season, he said: \"I will wait until the end of August.\"\n\nBarkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, appears destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a move to Tottenham, but Koeman said last week there had been no offers for the England international.", "id": "9510741", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Gylfi Sigurdsson close to signing for Everton - Ronald Koeman", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36038613.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-69d0daa2-bd67-464f-ac0d-321810283cb4_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 47, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby League", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Rugby_League"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 220, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 383, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 539, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/News and Media", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/News_and_Media"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 597, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/UEFA", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/UEFA"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 829, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy/Football", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy/Football"}], "time": "15:33:00"}

"eng-3364130", "body": "The 27-year-old Iceland midfielder has put pen to paper on a five-year contract and becomes the Toffees' eighth summer arrival.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson said.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction.\"\n\nSigurdsson's proposed move has dragged on for much of the summer, with Swansea initially valuing their star man at \u00a350m (\u20ac54.7m).\n\nFinally securing him now, at a slightly lower price, is set to take Everton's spending since the end of last season to over \u00a3140m (\u20ac153.3m).\n\nKoeman, who has already this summer brought in the likes of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klaassen, Sandro Ramirez, and Wayne Rooney, said of Sigurdsson: \"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season, with that we lost 25 goals, and we need players who will bring in productivity to the team.\n\n\"He is that type of player, with a lot of productivity.\n\n\"He knows the Premier League and he had really good seasons with Swansea.\n\nIn my opinion he is, in his position, one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nSigurdsson will not feature in tonight's Europa League qualifier first leg against Croatia's Hajduk Split (8.05pm, Goodison Park), but Koeman has indicated he could make his Everton debut in Monday's league clash with Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium.\n\nKoeman has said Everton are waiting to learn the severity of an apparent hamstring problem suffered by Ross Barkley.\n\nReports have suggested Barkley, whose future with the club remains unclear, is facing six weeks out due to a hamstring tear.\n\nAsked about that, Koeman said: \"He stopped training, I think it was last Monday. We need to wait.\"\n\nThe Dutchman added that there was \"no update\" in terms of the 23-year-old's \"situation\", and when asked if he was in his plans for the coming season, he said: \"I will wait until the end of August.\"\n\nBarkley, who is entering the last year of his contract, appears destined to leave the club having turned down the offer of a new deal.\n\nHe has been linked with a move "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Manager Koeman is determining to revamp the squad by signing Wayne Rooney, Michael Keane, Jordan Pickford and Sandro Ramirez\n\nIceland midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson is due to complete a \u00a345 million ($58m, 49.4m euros) move to Everton from Premier League rivals Swansea later on Wednesday if he passes a medical, British media reported.\n\nThe 27-year-old, due to sign a five year contract worth \u00a3100,000 a week, would be Everton's record signing, topping the \u00a331.8m they paid Chelsea for Romelu Lukaku in 2014.\n\nSigurdsson, who played a pivotal role in Swansea retaining their Premier League status last term after scoring nine goals and creating 13, pulled out of their pre-season tour to the United States and was not included in the squad for last weekend's 0-0 draw with Southampton.\n\nSwansea, who are also battling to keep Chelsea target and veteran Spanish striker Fernando Llorente, had wanted \u00a350m.\n\nThey have already turned down two bids from Everton and rejected a reported \u00a340m offer one from 2016 champions Leicester at the beginning of the summer.\n\nIt is believed, shareholder Farhad Moshiri has spent close to \u00a3100m so far in recruiting former favourite Wayne Rooney, goalkeeper Jordan Pickford (\u00a330m), midfielder Davy Klaassen (\u00a323.6m), defender Michael Keane (\u00a330m), Cuco Martina and Sandro Ramirez.\n\nHowever, a considerable proportion of the spending has been financed by the \u00a375m sale of striker Romelu Lukaku to Manchester United.\n\nThey could further balance the books with a big money sale of midfielder Ross Barkley to Tottenham Hotspur, although he is presently injured and likely to be out till October.\n\nIcelandic {"timeCrawl": "19:38:00", "uri": "710509596", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "source": {"title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "id": "713"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/everton-confirm-club-record-signing-swansea-citys-gylfi-sigurdsson-1635295", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Everton have confirmed the club-record signing of Icelandic international Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea City for a fee which could rise to \u00a345m.\n\nSigurdsson, 27, has signed a five-year deal with Ronald Koeman's men and is likely to be unveiled during his new side's Europa League play-off round clash against Hajduk Split at Goodison Park on Thursday (17 August).\n\nThe confirmation of the deal brings to an end over a month of posturing and infuriating negotiations. Swansea had initially placed a \u00a350m price tag on the talismanic playmaker during the embryonic stages of the summer transfer window, but Everton were reluctant to go so high for the former Tottenham attacker, who dragged Paul Clement's side away from the relegation mire last summer.\n\nClement said there was a \"difference of opinion\" over the fee last weekend but a deal was finally agreed on Tuesday, with Everton paying a set amount of \u00a340m with \u00a35m potentially to be worth in add-ons.\n\nKoeman has admired Sigurdsson for a long time and made him his top target this summer, and is delighted to have finally captured the former Reading academy product: \"I'm really happy because the Board and especially our Chairman, Bill Kenwright, did everything to get him. It took some time but finally we have signed the player,\" Koeman told evertontv.\n\n\"In my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League. We have the player here and that's really good for the team.\"\n\nEverton supporters may have to wait to see Sigurdsson make his debut for the club. The talented forward played just 45 minutes of football during pre-season and was omitted from Swansea's pre-season tour of America due to the speculation that surrounded him.\n\nSigurdsson may play some part against Manchester City on Monday, but for now is just delighted to have finally joined Everton: \"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\n\n\"For myself, I would like to score as many goals as possible and create as many goals for my teammates as I can. These are my targets. But it is always the same thing: as long as the team is winning I will be more than happy.\"\n\nSigurdsson is Everton twelfth signing of the summer, but Koeman is keen to bring a couple more players before the end of the transfer window. {"timeCrawl": "20:07:00", "uri": "710522163", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:07:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The World Game", "uri": "theworldgame.sbs.com.au", "id": "9752"}, "url": "http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/article/2017/08/17/sigurdsson-completes-club-record-move-swansea-everton", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Everton have completed the signing of Gyfli Sigurdsson, who has agreed a five-year deal after leaving Swansea City for a club-record fee reported to be \u00a345million ($73M).\n\nThe 27-year-old hit nine Premier League goals for Swansea last season, contributing 13 assists to keep his side in the top-flight.\n\nBut Sigurdsson has not featured for Swansea since pulling out of a pre-season tour to the United States, with Ronald Koeman having made the attacker one of his top transfer targets as he bids to take Everton into the Champions League.\n\nAnd, following weeks of negotiations, Sigurdsson has joined Wayne Rooney, Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Sandro Ramirez and Cuco Martina in moving to Goodison Park.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the Club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv upon signing.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\n\n\"For myself, I would like to score as many goals as possible and create as many goals for my team-mates as I can. These are my targets.\n\n\"But it is always the same thing: as long as the team is winning I will be more than happy.\"\n\nAnd Koeman was thrilled to finally land his man.\n\n\"I'm really happy because the board and especially our chairman, Bill Kenwright, did everything to get him. It took some time but finally we have signed the player,\" Koeman told evertontv.\n\n\"In my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League. {"timeCrawl": "09:17:00", "uri": "710220091", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T09:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Loans", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Loans"}], "time": "09:17:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "10:32:00", "uri": "710254457", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T10:16:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2017/aug/16/gylfi-sigurdsson-everton-swansea-transfer", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "A fee of \u00a345m may seem excessive but the quiet and dedicated Icelander is a set-piece master with a bright football brain and Everton are set to reap the benefits now the transfer saga is finally over\n\nIt turned into one of those dreaded transfer sagas, leaving senior figures at Swansea City and Everton exasperated with the snail's pace of the discussions to the point that even those on the inside became bored with the story, yet confirmation finally arrived on Tuesday evening that Gylfi Sigurdsson was on his way from the Mumbles to Merseyside for \u00a345m.\n\nThe passage of time - more than a month - has arguably diluted some of the excitement at one end and certainly the level of disappointment at the other. While Everton fans grew tired of waiting and, in some cases, started to question whether Sigurdsson was really worth all that hassle and money, the mood shifted in Swansea once it became clear that the Icelander wanted out and that any significant signings would not be made until the first instalment of the biggest transfer fee in their history had been handed over.\n\nAs for Sigurdsson, the man who covered more ground than any other Premier League player last season, 433km to be exact, watched the new season start without him and has not played a match of any description since he wore the captain's armband in a friendly defeat at Barnet on 12 July, when Swansea assumed that he would be boarding the flight to the United States the next day for the club's pre-season tour. Sigurdsson had other ideas and informed the club at the team hotel in London, shortly before they were due to depart for the airport, that he was staying at home.\n\nThat decision took Paul Clement by surprise and went down badly with Swansea's supporters. It would be naive to think that Sigurdsson's actions were all of his own doing - the mechanics behind a transfer are a bit more complicated than that - and it is also true that plenty of players have behaved in the same way to force through a move. With Sigurdsson, however, Swansea thought it would be different.\n\nA quiet man in the dressing room, Sigurdsson was always seen as a model professional, inspiring those around him with his performances and commanding the respect of players and staff with his dedication on the training ground. He was something of a reluctant hero at Swansea - an image stays in the mind of Sigurdsson on the final day of last season, during the players' lap of honour, being cajoled by a few of his team-mates to step forward and acknowledge the supporters that were singing his name to the tune of Give it Up by KC and The Sunshine Band.\n\nFour days earlier Sigurdsson had pretty much swept the board at the club's end-of-season awards dinner, winning players' player of the year for the second season running, supporters' player of the year and away supporters' player of the year. By the end of the evening he looked embarrassed to be spending so much time on the stage.\n\nKev Johns, the brilliant compere and a fanatical Swansea supporter, saw each on-stage interview as an opportunity to try - tongue-in-cheek - to talk Sigurdsson into staying, at one point jumping on the player's description of Swansea as a \"special club\". With a glint in his eye, Johns said: \"You do know it's not like that everywhere else.\" Sigurdsson laughed along with the rest of the guests, yet deep down most people at the Liberty Stadium that night would have suspected that his time in Wales was up.\n\nCertainly plenty of the players thought that was the case after another superb season from a man whose contribution over the past three years at Swansea shines through in the company that he has been keeping when it comes to the statistics that really matter. Sigurdsson has been directly involved in 53 Premier League goals since the start of the 2014-15 season, which as a midfielder is second only to Tottenham's Christian Eriksen.\n\nTo provide a bit of context, next on that list after Sigurdsson is Mesut \u00d6zil, then Eden Hazard, followed by Cesc F\u00e0bregas, Sadio Man\u00e9, Riyad Mahrez, Dele Alli, David Silva and Philippe Coutinho - you get the picture. Ross Barkley, for what it is worth, is down in 13th place. The Everton midfielder, and the man that Sigurdsson has effectively been bought to replace at Goodison Park, has been involved in 20 fewer league goals over the same period.\n\nNow take into consideration the fact that Sigurdsson has been scoring and creating all those goals in a team that has spent the last two seasons fighting relegation and it becomes a little easier to understand why Swansea put a \u00a350m valuation on his head, especially given the sort of transfer fees that have been paid elsewhere in the Premier League this summer and, in some cases, for players that are nothing like as influential.\n\nThere is a misconception about Sigurdsson that he is no more than a set-piece expert. Sigurdsson, without question, is brilliant in dead-ball situations. Every direct free-kick within shooting distance carried a huge sense of expectation at Swansea and the statistics covering the previous three seasons show that he is comfortably top of the pile for chances created from set-plays (106, more than twice as many as any Everton player), yet the 27-year-old has much more to his game.\n\nAn intelligent player who likes to roam and link play, Sigurdsson is at his best when he finds pockets of space to open teams up with a first-time pass or clever backheel. That bright football brain makes up for the fact that he lacks pace: he is, by his own admission, \"not the kind of player who is going to get the ball and run past the full-back\". For that reason Sigurdsson needs to play through the middle as a No10, where he can have the biggest impact on the game.\n\nAt Tottenham Hotspur, where Sigurdsson spent two seasons after joining from Hoffenheim in 2012, he was frustrated with how much time he spent on either the left wing or the bench. He made 58 Premier League appearances across two seasons with Spurs, yet was on the pitch from start to finish in only nine of those matches. Tottenham's loss ended up being Swansea's gain, as Mauricio Pochettino admitted last season. The Spurs manager said Sigurdsson would have been a \"perfect player\" for him at White Hart Lane, yet he never really got the chance to work with a midfielder who was in his starting lineup for a pre-season friendly against Seattle Sounders only to be sold 40 minutes before the game kicked off. Pochettino, who had only just taken over as manager, received a call from the Tottenham board to say that Ben Davies was joining from Swansea and Sigurdsson was going the other way.\n\nOn the back of an impressive loan spell a few seasons earlier, Swansea knew what they were getting with Sigurdsson in every sense. Managers, coaches and players came to admire his work ethic in training as much as his goals and assists on a match day. Team-mates would talk about the way the goalkeeper coach would look at Sigurdsson on a morning at the training ground and ask: \"Today?\" More often than not Sigurdsson would give a nod back, which meant that he wanted to do some extra shooting once the session had finished.\n\nSigurdsson preferred to do that work away from the rest of the outfield players so that there were no distractions. He would spend hours striking the ball from the edge of the area with both feet - naturally stronger on his right, he scored some terrific goals for Swansea with his left, and got his reward in those headline statistics. \"There is no luck involved,\" Jack Cork said at the end of last season, reflecting on the superb free-kick that Sigurdsson scored against Manchester United to earn Swansea a point in April. \"Gylfi spends ages practising. He works so hard.\"\n\nSigurdsson, in short, was a man who could do no wrong in the eyes of everyone at the club and few at the Liberty Stadium would have begrudged him a big move this summer. In truth, it was something of a surprise when Swansea managed to tie him down to a four-year contract 12 months earlier. Yet the way things were handled after the Barnet game last month left a bitter taste for some Swansea fans.\n\nIt is a shame in many ways, especially given the legacy that Sigurdsson could have left at Swansea, although there is nothing be gained by dwelling on the past. While Everton focus on getting their club-record signing match fit and integrated as soon as possible, Swansea need to move quickly to reinvest the money wisely. Time will tell whether all the haggling was worthwhile.", "id": "9455569", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Gylfi Sigurdsson: tireless perfectionist will be worth the wait for Everton | The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\"\n\nThe manager also confirmed he is still waiting to find out the extent be sold in the current transfer window.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" Koeman said. \"It looks like a hamstring injury, but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what laterInvalid Email\n\nMany people claim it's a prime example of the transfer market going mad.\n\nIn the eyes of many fans, Everton's pursuit of Swansea's Gylfi Sigurdsson perfectly illustrates the absurd, inflated nature of the transfer fees being bandied around this summer.\n\nAfter all, Everton agreeing a club record \u00a345million for a player at a team who were nearly relegated last season - that's a crazy amount of money... right?\n\nWrong, actually.\n\nAs the stats below clearly prove, Sigurdsson has been one of the Premier League's leading playmakers for several seasons now.\n\nIn fact, once you see some of these numbers - and once you consider how much Premier League clubs are currently paying for certain other players - you will no doubt agree that Sigurdsson could be a \u00a345miilion bargain...\n\nOver the course of the last three Premier League seasons, only four players have racked up more assists than Sigurdsson\n\nHere's the top five Premier League assisters since August 2014:\n\nCesc Fabregas (37), Mesut Ozil (33), Christian Eriksen (32), Kevin De Bruyne (27)... and Sigurdsson (26).\n\nNot bad for a guy playing for Swansea.\n\nSince he made his Premier League debut (2011), Gylfi Sigurdsson has scored more free-kick goals than any other player\n\nThe Icelandic international has scored SEVEN goals from direct free-kicks in that period - one more than Robert Snodgrass, Eriksen and Juan Mata (all on six).\n\nSigurdsson covered more distance in the Premier League than any other player in 2016/17\n\nThe fact Sigurdsson ran across a grand total of 433 kilometres during matches last season might not mean much on its own.\n\nIt means an awful lot more when you learn that no other player - in any position or at any club - ran further.\n\nOnly one player scored more goals against the Premier League's top six last season than Sigurdsson\n\nSigurdsson scored a remrkable five goals against the division's top sides last season.\n\nOnly Jamie Vardy (with six) bagged more against the best teams in the land.\n\nSigurdsson provided more assists from dead ball situations than any other player in the Premier League last season\n\nEight assists from set-pieces in one campaign?\n\nPositively Beckham-esque.\n\nSigurdsson was involved in 48.9% of Swansea's goals last season\n\nThat means he either scored or set up nearly half of the Swans' goals.\n\nOnly Jermain Defoe at Sunderland (58.6%) and Romelu Lukaku at Everton (50%) were involved in more for their side.\n\nSigurdsson is both Swansea's leading scorer (34) and assister (29) in The Sigurdsson deal will take Ronald Koeman's spending this summer to \u00a3131m, says the Daily Telegraph.\n\nAside from Sigurdsson and Pickford, the Toffees have made several other high profile signings this summer, including Michael Keane and Davy Klaassen, while Wayne Rooney has returned to his boyhood club on a free transfer.\n\nSwansea appeared resigned to the idea of selling Sigurdsson last week. Manager Paul Clement left him out of the squad that drew 0-0 with Southampton, says The Times.\n\nSigurdsson's arrival could spell the end for Ross Barkley at Everton but observers have mixed opinions about what he brings to the Toffees.\n\nThe transfer fee may at first seem like a \"stupid amount of money\", says Pat Nevin of the BBC. \"But if he goes and gets you into the Champions League, well that will not seem like a daft amount of money.\n\n\"There's a few of us out there who think this guy's extra special and can give you that one thing, that one piece of class that you need to make yourself different from the rest.\n\n\"Sigurdsson gets a game wherever he goes and looks perfectly good in any team you put him in. He's a fabulous player and I think he single-handedly kept his club up last season.\"\n\nBut Tom Ley of the US website Deadspin is less convinced. The Icelandic international is an \"attacking midfielder who can get himself a goal when needed and excels at picking out target men with crosses from set-pieces\", he says.\n\n\"There's nothing wrong with a player like that, but Everton already have two second striker-types in Klaassen and Rooney, and not much in the way of a target man... {"timeCrawl": "19:09:00", "uri": "710497674", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "SB Nation", "uri": "sbnation.com", "id": "962"}, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2017/8/16/16157318/gylfi-sigurdsson-to-everton-transfer-news", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Can the Icelandic star's set-piece delivery propel Everton past one of England's big six clubs?\n\nWhatever you think of Everton's transfer policy this summer, you certainly can't accuse them of lacking ambition. The Toffees identified Gylfi Sigurdsson as their top transfer target early in the summer and never relented in that pursuit, despite Swansea City rejecting multiple bids. And on Wednesday, Everton finally got their man for an incredible \u00a345 million transfer fee -- by far a club record.\n\nSigurdsson is the player who has received the most credit for keeping Swansea City in the Premier League last season. He recorded nine goals and 13 assists in league play, with many of both coming from set pieces.\n\nEverton has some fantastic defenders, athletes, ball-retainers, and finishers, but is currently lacking in the quality service department. Ronald Koeman believes Sigurdsson is his team's missing piece, and will expect him to rack up assists for the next few years.\n\nIt's likely that Sigurdsson will slot into Everton's starting XI on the right wing, but he's a versatile player who will likely line up in multiple spots based on the form and fitness of other players. Sigurdsson is a very two-footed player, and he's played on both wings, as a No. 10, and in a three-man midfield for both Tottenham Hotspur and Swansea City.\n\nThat versatility makes Sigurdsson an especially useful pickup for Everton given their set of youngsters currently fighting for playing time. Tom Davies is a central midfielder, Dominic Calvert-Lewin has played as an attacking midfielder and winger, and Ademola Lookman has played as a winger and forward. None is clearly head and shoulders above the others, but any of them could make a big leap forward and cement their place in the starting XI sometime this season.\n\nNo matter which player makes that leap, Sigurdsson can fit into a lineup with them. He doesn't block anyone, and no one blocks him. Sigurdsson's future position might be defined by which one of those players makes the most progress in the first half of the season.\n\nAfter years of frugal spending by chairman Bill Kenwright, Evertonians will be thrilled that new owner Farhad Moshiri was willing to spend whatever it took to get his manager's top transfer target. So if you're an Everton supporter who can't be bothered with worrying about the club's finances, stop reading here and don't let me drag you down. Celebrate and be happy. This is an incredible day for you.\n\nAre they gone? OK -- this is a bad deal. Sigurdsson is a good player who will slot into Everton's starting XI right away and make them better, but he will not make them better enough to get into the top four. He is not the difference between seventh and fourth. Everton had the seventh-best squad in the Premier League before signing Sigurdsson, and after signing him they have ... the seventh-best squad in the Premier League.\n\nThis is the predicament that clubs outside of the rich top-six set face -- there is no one signing, or even half-dozen signings, they can realistically make to bridge the gap. The only way to do it is, as Tottenham has, slowly but surely increase your commercial revenue while hitting the lottery on some very cheap signings or academy products that turn into superstars.\n\nSigurdsson is turning 28 in less than a month, so he has very little resale value. He's signing a contract with wages big enough that no smaller club will want to match if he is anything less than a superstar for Everton. Players like this should only be signed if a team has reason to believe that they are one player away from a Champions League place/league title, or if their revenue is so high that the loss they take on the player will be irrelevant. Neither applies to Everton.\n\nA team that nearly got relegated last season, and who has done very little to improve this summer, just sold their best player by several orders of magnitude. Yikes.\n\nSwansea now has two weeks to spend \u00a345 million wisely enough that it gives them one of the 17 best squads in the Premier League. Given that their transfer window was a disaster last summer as well, this seems unlikely. The Swans might have sold a player for double what he should be worth, but they also made themselves strong relegation favorites. Maybe Sigurdsson isn't worth \u00a345 million on the open market, but there's a good chance he was actually worth much more than that to the Swans.\n\nThis appears to be a rare lose-lose transfer, with both teams making bad deals.", "id": "9547522", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Gylfi Sigurdsson's \u00a345m transfer is a lose-lose for Everton and Swansea", "image": {"timeCrawl": "20:45:00", "uri": "710536302", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:45:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "WalesOnline", "uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "id": "1272"}, "url": "http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/gylfi-sigurdsson-finally-completes-record-13487769", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Get rugby updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nGylfi Sigurdsson has completed his record \u00a345m move to Everton - leaving Swansea City looking to make swift progress on their bid to replace him.\n\nAnd there are hopes that as many as three new faces could arrive to soften the blow at the Liberty before time is called on summer business.\n\nSigurdsson was finally confirmed as an Everton player yesterday evening, signing a five-year deal and bringing to an end a year-long chase from the Toffees for the 27-year-old.\n\nIt has been a pursuit that has come to a head over the past month, with both Everton and Swansea locked in tense talks following Sigurdsson's refusal to head off on pre-season tour with the rest of Paul Clement's squad -- a move that put the Liberty club in no doubt the 27-year-old had his sights set on a move to Goodison.\n\nYet a deal was only thrashed out and agreed in the past few days, which now leaves Swansea up against the clock in a bid to bring in the necessary reinforcements before the August 31 transfer deadline.\n\nSwansea have already made initial approaches for West Brom's Nacer Chadli, Manchester City striker Wilfried Bony while also making a \u00a320m bid for ex-youth star Joe Allen, though they are not thought to be the only targets.\n\nClement claimed last week he was confident the club would be able to move quickly to strengthen his squad once Sigurdsson's move had been made formal, but will now want to make sure his confidence was well-placed.\n\nIn their statement confirming the deal, Swansea declared the fee as undisclosed, though it is thought to be a package worth around \u00a345m, with \u00a340m of which is guaranteed and the remainder in add-ons. It breaks the \u00a328m record fee received by Swansea for a player when Bony was sold to Manchester City in 2015, as well as becoming the biggest transfer fee paid in Everton's history.\n\nEverton boss Ronald Koeman believes that has bought his side \"one of the best players in the Premier League\", while Sigurdsson claimed working under the former Barcelona and Netherlands ace was a huge factor in wanting to quit Swansea.\n\nSigurdsson, Swansea's player of the year for the past two seasons, said: \"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time. Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. He has built up a really good squad here, with strong players, both young and experienced. This was a key factor for me.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\"\n\nKoeman added: \"It took some time but finally we have signed the player (who) in my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League. We have the player here and that's really good for the team.\n\n\"From the beginning, he was one of the key players we wanted to bring to Everton. That's because of his quality, first and foremost, and his experience in the Premier League.\n\n\"We need more productivity. We don't sign one player who will score 25 goals but we need several players around our striker to get that number. He is one of those productive players which he has shown at Swansea and also in the past.\n\n\"He can play in different positions. "eng-3363222", "body": "The Magpies are reportedly set to sign Stoke City's Joselu in the next 24 hours\n\nGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nHuddersfield Town could face a Newcastle United side buoyed by a new signing on Super Sunday this weekend.\n\nThe Toon are chasing Stoke City striker Joselu, with reports suggesting a deal could be done in the next 24 hours.\n\nThe Spaniard has struggled for form during his time at the Bet365 Stadium since joining from Hannover in 2015 for around \u00a36m, with the 27-year-old scoring four goals in 27 appearances in his first season.\n\nHis lack of goals for the Potters meant he was sent out on loan to Deportivo La Coruna last term, where he notched six in 24 appearances.\n\nAnd the Telegraph are now reporting that the 6'3\" forward is due to complete a \u00a37m move to the north east in the next 24 hours.\n\nJoselu has been a long-term target for {"timeCrawl": "09:30:00", "uri": "710794245", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:30:00Z", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "source": {"title": "Stoke Sentinel", "uri": "stokesentinel.co.uk", "id": "1747"}, "url": "http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/creative-explosive-jese-can-get-fans-flocking-to-stoke-city-says-graham-hunter/story-30485586-detail/story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3371616", "body": "Jese Rodriguez has the tempo-setting, game-changing potential to get fans queuing up to watch Stoke City , says Spanish football expert Graham Hunter.\n\nIt wasn't all that long ago that Jese was breaking through at Real Madrid, keeping current favourite Isco on the bench and being tipped for stardom with club and country.\n\nIt is fair to say the last three years haven't gone to plan, with a horrendous knee injury followed by difficult spells at Paris St Germain and Las Palmas.\n\nBut what he showed, believes Hunter, should still be enough for everyone at Stoke to be very excited.\n\nHe said: \"The physical training of the Premier League should be very good for him and it will help that the manager can speak a little bit of Spanish.\n\n\"I'm not saying it will be easy. It's very different in terms of culture and climate, even from Paris, than he would have ever experienced in his life. He's still only 24.\n\n\"He needs to be fit and he needs to be focused but if he can get back to the form he showed at Real Madrid - creative, cheeky, explosive, technically very gifted - then people will be flocking to watch Stoke. He's that good.\n\n\"They have brought in quality so it will all depend if the timing is right. I really hope it's a success.\"\n\nRead more: Arsenal game can transform perception of Stoke City, says Robbie Earle\n\nA move to Stoke at this stage of Jese's career would have seemed outlandish when he made his first steps in the senior game, breaking records for Real Madrid's B side.\n\nIt wasn't easy getting a chance in an attacking department featuring Cristiano Ronaldo, Angel di Maria, Mesut Ozil, Kaka, Gonzalo Higuain and Karim Benzema but he always backed himself, it turned out with good reason.\n\nHunter said: \"When Jese burst onto the scene at Real Madrid he was absolutely exceptional. He's one of those footballers with cheek and creativity and before that brutal injury he was also very explosive.\n\n\"There was a time when he was scoring for Real Madrid Castilla - he got 22 in 38 - when he gave a long interview which included criticism of Jose Mourinho. He didn't feel he was getting the chance he should in view of his goals or the fact he had come through the system.\n\n\"Yet when he was promoted by Carlo Ancelotti it became clear he wasn't simply a goal scorer, he would link play and had the ingenuity to go past a man. He was always looking for ways to score.\n\n\"He was the type of footballer that would change the tempo of a match and get supporters on the edge of their seats. He had great pace and the drive and it was telling that Vicente del Bosque was talking about including him in the World Cup squad.\n\n\"This was the Spain team that were reigning world and European champions and to be in consideration, having played relatively so few games for Real Madrid, was no small thing.\"\n\nRead more: Referee for Stoke City v Arsenal announced\n\nA freak incident in a 9-1 aggregate Champions League win over Schalke in February 2014, however, would put a big dent in his progression.\n\nHe would spend nine months out and even though he came back into the squad under Zinedine Zidane , things would never be the same again. Perhaps a second career in hip hop - or reggaeton to be exact, under the stage name Jey M - didn't help either.\n\nHunter explained: \"It was an innocuous challenge that would keep him out for so long. Maybe there was a little bit of a rush to come back and he had an infection which set him back. On top of that there was a fire at his house which can't have helped the mental stain. He ended up being out for more than he needed to be.\n\n\"It was that explosive pace, the ability to get across the length of the pitch like Gareth Bale and destabilise an opponent that maybe were undermined by the injury. Real Madrid didn't look particularly like his second career in reggaeton either and there were suggestions he didn't have that same drive that he had shown when he was coming through.\"\n\nJey M released a single - Yo Sabia , with the chorus, 'Let's make love like it's the last time' - last summer and Jese moved on, joining Paris St Germain on a five-year contract for \u00a322m.\n\n\"Unfortunately at Paris St Germain he bumped into a coach with whom he didn't see eye to eye,\" said Hunter. \"Unai Emery is very, very strict about team patterns while Jese is a guy who craves the freedom to cause positive anarchy.\n\n\"Going home to Las Palmas should have been the perfect move but he walked into a club that had real disunity, the coach was falling out with the board and it didn't work out.\"\n\nThere is hope in Spain that it will be different this time.\n\nHunter said: \"Jese might be too young to have seen Mark Hughes play for Barcelona but he will have He scored twice in nine appearances before being loaned to Spanish side Las Palmas for the second half of the season.\n\nBefore joining PSG, Rodriguez spent nine seasons at Real, scoring 12 times in 62 La Liga appearances. He won the Champions League in 2014 and 2016 before a knee injury stalled his progress.\n\n\"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes told the club's website (www.stokecityfc.com).\n\nRodriguez follows Darren Fletcher, Kurt Zouma, Eric Maxim
