{"timeCrawl": "21:35:00", "uri": "709986774", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T21:35:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"title": "Deadspin", "uri": "deadspin.com", "id": "3274"}, "url": "http://deadspin.com/what-will-everton-actually-get-from-gylfi-sigurdsson-1797869955", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "After weeks and weeks of speculation, rumors, and false starts, it looks like Everton are finally getting their man. According to the BBC, the Toffees have agreed to a \u00a345 million fee for Swansea midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson. So now what?\n\nEverton have had an interesting summer. They've spent like crazy, having brought in seven new first-team players, including Sigurdsson. A team that spends that much, particularly one that goes out and spends \u00a345 million on one guy, is usually looking to make a leap into the next tier of its league. Everton are a bit of a unique case, though, given that all this money has been spent to fill holes left by the departure of Romelu Lukaku, perhaps the best striker in England, and the soon-to-be-departed Ross Barkley, a probably overrated player who nevertheless has been a key fixture in the lineup.\n\nFor most of the summer, it wasn't hard to see what manager Ronald Koeman was after: an improved defense (Michael Keane, Jordan Pickford), and enough scorers to patch together the 25 goals Lukaku took with him (Davy Klaassen, Wayne Rooney, Sandro Ramirez). All that was missing, then, was the kind of creative midfield player that Barkley (theoretically) is, one capable of supplying all those new scorers with chances.\n\nOn the surface, Sigurdsson seems to scratch that itch. He finished last season with nine goals and 13 assists in 38 appearances. Eight of those assists came from set-pieces, though, and 38 of the chances he created last season came from corner kicks. When you zero in on just the chances Sigurdsson created from open play last season, he suddenly looks a lot less like the creative playmaker Everton are in need of:\n\nSo, Sigurdsson profiles as an attacking midfielder who can get himself a goal when needed and excels at picking out target men with crosses from set-pieces. There's nothing wrong with a player like that, but Everton already have two second striker-types in Klaassen and Rooney, and not much in the way of a target man.\n\nAt Swansea, Sigurdsson had the 6-foot-5 Fernando Llorente to fire his crosses at, but as Everton are currently constituted he'll be trying to pick out Wayne Rooney, Sandro Ramirez, and Dominic Calvert-Lewin in the box, all of whom are 5-foot-9.\n\nThe transfer window isn't closed, of course, and it's entirely possible that Everton still have a big striker on their transfer wish list. There have been rumors about a move for Olivier Giroud, Christian Benteke, or even Danny Welbeck, but so far none of those seem all that close to happening. Unless a player like that is brought in before the window closes, it's hard to see how Sigurdsson fits into the side or provides anything Everton don't already have.\n\nThat's a strange thing to say about a player that costs \u00a345 million, but such is life in the post-TV money era of EPL inflation. For a price that used to fetch a season-altering star player, Everton have acquired a guy who, unless another move is made soon, may very well end up spending the season doing little more than {"timeCrawl": "18:48:00", "uri": "710489796", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:48:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "evertonfc.com", "uri": "evertonfc.com", "id": "5173"}, "url": "http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2017/08/16/sigurdsson-joins-everton-in-club-record-deal", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Gylfi Sigurdsson has vowed to \"create goals\" and \"score goals\" for ambitious Everton after completing his Club-record move to the Blues on a five-year deal from Swansea City.\n\nThe 27-year-old midfielder is Everton's eighth new signing of the summer and, after penning a contract until the end of June 2022, has been hailed as one of the Premier League's best players by his new manager Ronald Koeman.\n\nThe 6ft 1in Iceland international spent the past three seasons with Swansea and was directly involved in 21 Premier League goals last term. He also covered the greatest distance covered by any top-flight player during the season - 433 kilometres - and has been directly involved in 53 league goals since the start of 2014/15 - second only as a midfielder to Tottenham's Christian Eriksen.\n\nEverton boss Koeman was thrilled to capture one of his prime targets, who he believes will add \"productivity\" to his ambitious team.\n\nAnd Sigurdsson is eager to deliver what his new manager is looking for.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the Club,\" Sigurdsson told evertontv.\n\n\"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction. The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\n\n\"For myself, I would like to score as many goals as possible and create as many goals for my teammates as I can. These are my targets.\n\n\"But it is always the same thing: as long as the team is winning I will be more than happy.\"\n\nSigurdsson also acknowledged that the prospect of working under Koeman - twice a European Cup winner as a player - further fuelled his desire to play for Everton.\n\n\"He was a great player, one of the top players of his time,\" said Sigurdsson. \"Now he is a really good manager and his vision for Everton is clear. He has built up a really good squad here, with strong players, both young and experienced.\n\n\"This was a key factor for me. Ultimately, that is a dream of mine and everyone at this Club. I know the supporters and players would agree with that.\"\n\nKoeman was delighted to land a player he revealed had been in his sights for some time.\n\n\"I'm really happy because the Board and especially our Chairman, Bill Kenwright, did everything to get him. It took some time but finally we have signed the player,\" Koeman told evertontv.\n\n\"In my opinion, in his position he is one of the best in the Premier League. We have the player here and that's really good for the team.\"\n\nBorn in Reykjav\u00edk, Sigurdsson began his youth career in his homeland with Fimleikaf\u00e9lag Hafnarfjar\u00f0ar (FH) and Brei\u00f0ablik UBK, before moving to English shores to join Reading as a 16-year-old.\n\nHe signed for 1899 Hoffenheim in 2010, with fans voting for him as their Player of the Season, before he joined Swansea on loan on New Year's Day 2012.\n\nBut a permanent transfer to the Swans collapsed and Tottenham Hotspur swooped. He spent two seasons at White Hart Lane, scoring eight goals in 58 top-flight appearances, but then re-joined the Swans for a second spell. He was named the Swans' Player of the Year in both 2015/16 and 2016/17, his displays establishing him as a firm fans' favourite at the Liberty Stadium.\n\nOn the international stage, the midfielder starred for Iceland as they reached the quarter finals of Euro 2016. He scored twice in nine appearances before being loaned to Spanish side Las Palmas for the second half of the season.\n\nBefore joining PSG, Rodriguez spent nine seasons at Real, scoring 12 times in 62 La Liga appearances. He won the Champions League in 2014 and 2016 before a knee injury stalled his progress.\n\n\"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes told the club's website (www.stokecityfc.com).\n\nRodriguez follows Darren Fletcher, Kurt Zouma, Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting, Bruno Martins Indi and Josh Tymon to the club.\n\nStoke, who host Arsenal in the league on Saturday, were beaten 1-0 by Everton in their season opener at the weekend.\n\n($1 = 0.7771 Those kind of players cost upwards of \u00a320million but it's now looking clearer and clearer than Newcastle won't be spending that kind of money anytime soon.\n\nInstead Rafa Benitez is looking for bargains and that is why he's ended up spending \u00a35million on a striker who couldn't get a game for Stoke.\n\nThat does not mean it's not potentially a good signing. It took some time but finally we have signed the player,\" Koeman told evertontv. \"Of course, from the beginning, he was one of the key players we wanted to bring to Everton. That's because of his quality first and foremost and his experience in the Premier League.\n\n\"We need more productivity. We don't sign one player who will score 25 goals but we need several players around our striker to get that number. He is one of those productive players - he's shown that at Swansea and also in the past.\n\n\"In my opinion, in his position, he is one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nAt 27, Koeman believes Sigurdsson is joining the Toffees at the ideal stage of his career - and perfectly complements the other seven players who have been recruited during the summer transfer window.\n\n\"What you like to have is a balance in your team,\" he explained. \"We signed Sandro, 22, Pickford, 23, Keane and Klaassen, both 24, then also you need players like Rooney, experienced players who know how to win and who are good teachers for young players.\n\n\"Gylfi is one of those players like Rooney, a quality player who knows a lot in the Premier League. He will also be an important player in our set plays. He is what we need to find that balance in the team.\"\n\nDiscussing where Sigurdsson fits into his side, Koeman says he has a player who can be deployed in a number of midfield roles, explaining: \"Gylfi can play in different positions. {"timeCrawl": "14:07:00", "uri": "710923445", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:07:00Z", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "source": {"title": "evertonfc.com", "uri": "evertonfc.com", "id": "5173"}, "url": "http://www.evertonfc.com/news/2017/08/17/exciting-times-boost-everton-appeal", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Gylfi Sigurdsson radiated happiness. He covered a host of topics during an insightful 10-minute conversation and the beaming smile never left his face.\n\nSigurdsson talked of scoring and creating goals, of giving his peak footballing years to Everton.\n\nThe 27-year-old was speaking to evertontv about the pride and excitement he felt on completing his move to Goodison Park.\n\nIt has become a wonderfully familiar accompaniment to an invigorating summer: the sight and sound of men genuinely thrilled to be able to call themselves Everton footballers.\n\nAnd these aren't just any old footballers, either. Among their number is the most promising young goalkeeper in the land. A defender who won his first England cap earlier this year and possesses the attributes and aura to be the bedrock of Everton's rearguard for some years to come - his country's as well.\n\nThe young Dutch international from Ajax, a striker admired by Real Madrid and who shone for Spain at the European Under-21 Championship... and England's record international goalscorer.\n\nAs he outlined his reasons for joining Everton, Sigurdsson referenced the \"intent\" shown by the Club in this transfer window. The numbers reflect that ambition - the gifted midfielder from Swansea became the Blues' record signing when he penned his five-year deal. It was the third time Everton have upped that mark inside two months, following the purchases of Jordan Pickford and Michael Keane.\n\nSeeing Sigurdsson so at ease in his new environment and looking every inch the Evertonian in his pristine blue training kit, was to be reminded of another first-rate footballer who signed for the Blues when his career was at its apogee.\n\nJoe Royle set his sights high after winning the FA Cup in 1995 and went all out to bring one of Manchester United's best players to Goodison Park.\n\nIt took a while - but, in late August, Andrei Kanchelskis signed for Everton. As he posed for pictures - these were the days when a player unveiling amounted to him being snapped hoisting the Club scarf above his head - Kanchelskis cut the same contented, peppy figure as Sigurdsson would 22 years later.\n\nHe was gushing about signing for Everton, too, underlining his delight at joining a \"big club\" with big ambitions.\n\nLuring one of Manchester United's prized assets to Goodison was a significant coup for Royle, no doubt. The manager of the day knew all about Everton, though. He had won the league title playing for the Club.\n\nRoyle went at this deal emboldened by his inherent belief that Everton was the pinnacle - and able to dangle the Cup so memorably won at Wembley months previously in front of Kanchelskis as tangible proof of a team on an upwards trajectory.\n\nSimilarly, when Everton fended off the challenge of Arsenal to sign Tony Cottee in a British-record deal in 1988, the Londoner from West Ham knew he was joining a side who, one year earlier, had been English champions.\n\nCottee was 23 when he made his Blues' debut. Kanchelskis joined as a 26-year-old.\n\nIn both instances, Everton was a relatively easy sell to these excellent, aspirational young footballers.\n\nAnd as Sigurdsson effused about the prospect of working with Ronald Koeman, one of the European game's most revered personalities, he unwittingly gave an insight into what an attractive proposition the Club is right now.\n\nHe was similarly enthusiastic about his fellow Goodison new boys and the scale of the ambition Everton have displayed by signing Pickford, Keane, Davy Klaassen, Sandro Ramirez and Wayne Rooney.\n\nTellingly, Sigurdsson, unprompted, also mentioned the young players who form an essential part of Koeman's vision for a powerful and successful Everton.\n\nThat Tom Davies, Dominic Calvert-Lewin, Ademola Lookman and Mason Holgate were all in the Blues' first Premier League squad this season, points to the fact Koeman is developing something sustainable.\n\nThis is not a manager overseeing a scattergun transfer policy with no thought for what happens beyond this current campaign.\n\nKoeman has adopted Royle's attitude of Everton being a place where any footballer worth his salt should want to play.\n\nFor his plans to come to fruition, the boss has required the unstinting backing of the Blues' like-minded Chairman and board.\n\nYou don't land an individual like Sigurdsson without everybody working from the same page.\n\nMuch less would a player of the Icelander's calibre be so full of beans at the thought of playing for Everton if he didn't sense the Club was making a concerted effort to compete with the elite.\n\nThere are a plethora of statistics to illustrate just why Koeman so eagerly coveted Sigurdsson.\n\nThe numbers - revolving around the player's goalscoring prowess, creativity and running capacity - all add up to something rather special.\n\nYou need only watch him in action, though, to appreciate what a sublime talent Sigurdsson possesses.\n\nHis willingness to put in the hard yards is relevant, too. Examples are legion of a team's star turn refusing to dig in when the going gets tough.\n\nSigurdsson, though, took it upon himself to do something about Swansea's plight last season, when the Welsh side's dicey start to the campaign left them staring a relegation battle square in the face.\n\nHe was vital to Swansea's eventual Premier League survival, providing a potent cocktail of goals - either from his own boot, or by teeing up teammates to score - and readiness to get stuck in, reflected in the fact he ran further than any player in the division last season.\n\nFootball is about entertainment, too. Watching Sigurdsson glide across the pitch, his boots making a passing acquaintance with the turf, is a joy. His quick-witted passing and knack for making the right decisions in possession will go down well at Goodison - with team-mates and supporters alike.\n\nKanchelskis was, by Royle's reckoning, \"truly phenomenal,\" during his first campaign at Goodison - when Everton finished in sixth spot.\n\nEverton spent \u00a35million on the exhilarating Ukranian winger - at a time when the British transfer record was \u00a38.5million, a decidedly sober figure by modern standards.\n\n\"Crazy,\" Sigurdsson laughed as he considered today's transfer fees.\n\nEverton's business this summer, though, is anything but. The Blues recruitment so far has been sagacious, sensible... and enormously exciting.", "id": "9705412", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Exciting Times Boost Everton Appeal", "image": {"timeCrawl": "14:41:00", "uri": "710375125", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:41:00Z", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "source": {"title": "Sky Sports", "uri": "skysports.com", "id": "709"}, "url": "http://www.skysports.com/football/news/15134/10991250/gylfi-sigurdsson-to-everton-but-is-the-midfielder-value-for-money", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Adam Bate\n\nComment and Analysis @ghostgoal\n\nGylfi Sigurdsson to Everton: But is the midfielder value for money?\n\nLast Updated: 16/08/17 3:16pm\n\nGylfi Sigurdsson's move to Everton promises much given the Iceland international's impressive statistics, but could they be misleading? Adam Bate delves deeper into the data to find out.\n\nThere is no doubt that Sigurdsson played a key role in Swansea's survival. With nine goals and 13 assists, he was directly involved in more of the Swans' strikes than any other player, scoring winners against Liverpool and Southampton and a late equaliser at Old Trafford. He was duly named player of the season by both supporters and team-mates.\n\nSo perhaps it should be no surprise that Everton were desperate to bring Sigurdsson to Goodison Park. They will have been further encouraged by the fact that the 28-year-old attacking midfielder covered more ground than any other Premier League player last season. He ranked third in the country for assists and was seventh for total chances created.\n\nBut curiously, there are doubts about the robustness and repeatability of what Sigurdsson achieved at Swansea. In particular, a deeper look at those assists raises issues. According to Opta, although Sigurdsson registered 13 of them, the number of goals that Swansea might have expected to score from the opportunities he fashioned last season was only 6.85.\n\nWhat are expected assists?\n\nOpta says: \"The Expected Assist Model measure the likelihood that a pass will be a goal assist based on where the pass was received, what type of pass it was and a variety of other factors.\"\n\nThe reason for this is that the quality of chance being created by Sigurdsson was not particularly high. This is largely because an extraordinarily high number of them came from set-pieces rather than open play. Fifty-two of the chances Sigurdsson created were from dead-ball situations - nobody else in the Premier League could come up with more than 40.\n\nIn fact, Sigurdsson was credited with 38 chances created from corner kicks alone. There are a number of reasons why this could be problematic. While Sigurdsson's delivery is undoubtedly impressive, these are generally considered difficult opportunities to convert - often headers that are being won under pressure amidst a crowd of bodies.\n\nThat the number is so high surely owes much to the abilities of his targets in the penalty box. Eleven of those chances created from corners found their way to 6'4\" striker Fernando Llorente, renowned for his heading ability. A further 13 were to Alfie Mawson, a young defender who scored seven goals in a season at both Barnsley and Wycombe Wanderers.\n\nNext on the list? That's Mawson's fellow defender Federico Fernandez. Indeed, defenders were the recipients of the majority of these chances - a reflection of the fact that more than two thirds of all chances created by Sigurdsson were headers. Fernandez got on the end of five corners without finding the net. In fact, only one of them was even on target.\n\nJust because Llorente, Mawson and Fernandez are capable of diverting an outswinging corner in the general direction of the goal - and 28 of these 38 chances were from right-wing corners - does not necessarily mean the numbers are transferable to another club. Tellingly, only three of these corners actually resulted directly in Swansea goals.\n\nOf course, expertise from set plays is not a negative. The fact that Swansea ranked in the top three in the Premier League for both headed and set-piece goals was a huge factor in their survival. Everton surely plan to put Sigurdsson on corners and free-kicks in the expectation that he can help to boost their own numbers in this regard.\n\nMoreover, the fact that this skill is such a big part of Sigurdsson's game adds context to the question marks over his age relative to his price. While he could be on the cusp of a downturn in output at 28, his set-piece delivery is unlikely to suffer into this 30s. That will bring confidence that he will be a useful asset for the full length of his next contract.\n\nMan City vs Everton\n\nAugust 21, 2017, 7:00pm\n\nLive on\n\nGet Sky Sports Get a Sky Sports pass\n\nHowever, it is vital that Everton appreciate what they would be getting for their huge investment. While the headline numbers put Sigurdsson in the top bracket of Premier League creators alongside Kevin De Bruyne, Christian Eriksen, Mesut Ozil and David Silva, the type and quality of the chances they supply for team-mates are actually very different.\n\nTo illustrate the point further, there are 71 players who created more open-play chances than Sigurdsson in the Premier League last season. That included Kevin Mirallas and three other Everton players. Ross Barkley created 54 such chances. Sigurdsson managed only 25 - the same number that Gareth Barry and Idrissa Gueye produced in fewer games.\n\nEven from set plays, it is uncertain how much of an impact that Sigurdsson might have at Everton given that Barkley, Mirallas and Baines shared the team's set-piece duties last term, creating 51 opportunities in the process - only one fewer than Sigurdsson. A quality player then, but one whose signature comes with considerable caveats.\n\nAlso See: Transfer Centre Latest transfer news", "id": "9500921", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": contributed 13 assists last season to help Swansea avoid relegation from the Premier League.\n\nHis 34 goals are the most scored by any Swansea player in the Premier League, and is also their leading creative influence with 29 assists.\n\nThe \u00a345m fee is \u00a35m less than the Swans wanted for Sigurdsson.\n\nSwansea have been linked with their former midfielder Joe Allen from Stoke City and arm and set to miss Saturday home game against Manchester United.\n\n\"Swansea have got a lot of hard work now, [Swansea manager] Paul Clement has got to have two or three players in the pipeline For me, it's the best league in the world. I want to play, enjoy and score a lot of goals at St James' Park in a Newcastle shirt.\n\n\"For me, it's a pleasure to be again in the Premier League. Newcastle is a big club and its an honour for me to play at this club in this amazing city.\n\n\"It's not about why I moved from Stoke to here. When Rafa called me, I didn't have to think any more about it, and now I am here and I want to enjoy it.\n\n\"Newcastle have a very good team and very good players as well. We will try to do our best home and away. We will try to win all the games to stay again in the Premier League.\"\n\nJoselu trained with his new team-mates in front of around 5,000 fans on St James' Park on Thursday as the club staged an open day.\n\nThe event came four days after the Magpies opened their first season back in the Premier League with an eventful 2-0 home defeat by Tottenham which saw defenders Florian Lejeune and Paul Dummett limp off before the break and Jonjo Shelvey sent off shortly after it.\n\nIt may not have been the result skipper Jamaal Lascelles and his colleagues craved, but he insists last season's Sky Best Championship title winners can make an impact in the top flight.\n\nLascelles said: \"We are here to compete. It will be tough - it's the best league in the world, some great players, great teams - but we did well in the Championship and now we need to take that through to the Premier League.\n\n\"It's football, anything can happen. We have got the right attitude, the right mentality - we are ambitious and we have got a team full of winners, as everyone saw last season.\n\n\"We would go a goal down, but we would come back and win the game. opening game defeat to Tottenham - Dummett pulling a hamstring and French debutant Lejeune damaging ankle ligaments after being on the receiving end of a nasty scissor challenge from England striker Harry Kane.\n\nIt was feared the defenders could be out for a lengthy spell to add to Benitez's worries as he tries to get the best out his wafer-thin squad.\n\nBut after initial assessments, the {"timeCrawl": "21:45:00", "uri": "710559570", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:30:00Z", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/16/everton-ronald-koeman-sigurdsson-new-striker-europa-league", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "* Manager wants a No9 to replace Romelu Lukaku's goals\n\n* 'It needs to be a player of a certain quality or a young player who can improve'\n\nEverton may be breaking their transfer record to sign \u00a345m Gylfi Sigurdsson from Swansea City but as far as Ronald Koeman is concerned the club still has business to do before the transfer window closes.\n\n\"We still need to sign a striker,\" the Everton manager said. \"Everybody knows that we lost Romelu Lukaku. We brought in Wayne Rooney, Sandro Ram\u00edrez and now Gylfi, and maybe they can share the goals around more than happened last season, but we still need another one to play the No9. When you play in Europe, and let's hope we reach Europe, and in the Premier League you cannot do it with just one or two strikers.\"\n\nEverton, whose summer spending now stands at \u00a3131m, were linked with Arsenal's Olivier Giroud last month, though the French striker appears to have made his peace with Ars\u00e8ne Wenger, and Koeman no longer believes there is any possibility of a deal. He admits time is running out and that it is difficult to sign top quality players when you cannot offer Champions League football - unless they can deal with the threat of Hajduk Split in the play-off round that begins on Thursday Everton will not even be in a position to offer Europa League football - but remains hopeful at least one of his targets will be landed before the end of the month. Koeman would also like left-sided cover for Leighton Baines in defence, though a striker is a clear priority.\n\n\"We have signed Sandro and Wayne, and we know the development of Dominic [Calvert-Lewin], but we are looking for an extra striker and it is difficult because it needs to be a player of a certain quality or a young player who can improve,\" Koeman said. \"We know we have the possibility to sign good players but we don't play Champions League and that sometimes makes decisions very difficult.\"\n\nIt was never a difficult decision for the Everton manager to go after Sigurdsson, a player he tried to sign when in charge of Southampton, though Koeman did admit to finding it surprisingly hard to let go of Gareth Barry, who has joined West Bromwich Albion in search of more regular football and the five games he needs to pass Ryan Giggs's all-time record of Premier League appearances.\n\n\"We tried when I was at Southampton to sign Sigurdsson but we did not have the finance that we have here at Everton,\" he said. \"In my opinion, in his position, he is one of the best players in the Premier League. We want more productivity in the team after losing Lukaku and that is exactly what Gylfi brings. We have worked a long time to get this deal done but he is one of the key players we wanted to bring in. Last season apart from Lukaku we did not have one player who scored 10 goals. Now, with Gylfi, Wayne and Sandro, we think that might be different.\"\n\nKoeman revealed he had been open to keeping the experienced Barry in the squad but the player realised he faced much stiffer competition for first-team places.\n\n\"You never want to lose a top professional like Gareth but I could understand his position,\" he said. \"He knew he would not be appearing every week and he is still the type of player who wants to keep playing. I let him go because I respect him, but I still had to ask myself whether we had enough midfield cover. I think we probably have, with Morgan Schneiderlin, Tom Davies and Muhamed Besic, maybe even Davy Klaassen if necessary, but of course I don't know how the season will go so I don't have that answer now. Maybe I will get a headache one day wondering why I let Gareth go.\"\n\nKoeman is open to loan moves as well as a permanent transfer - although he laughed at the suggestion Diego Costa might be a possibility - and is pleased with the business done in the window so far. \"We have brought in some good young players in important positions and that is good for the future of the club,\" he said. \"We are still trying to get more but they have to be of the best quality. "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Get Everton FC updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nEverton have broke their transfer record for the second time this summer after securing an eye-watering \u00a340m deal to land Swansea star Gylfi Sigurdsson.\n\nBlues boss Ronald Koeman made the Iceland international a top priority earlier this transfer window, and protracted negotiations finally came to a conclusion this week.\n\nThe playmaker has forged a reputation as one of the finest attacking midfielders in the top flight during his time with the Swans, and becomes the most expensive player in Everton history.\n\nBreaking their own transfer record twice in the same summer is the kind of scenario Everton fans have only dreamt about in the Premier League era.\n\nThe age of austerity is over for them, and seemingly everyone else in the top flight.\n\nAnd while some may baulk at the gigantic fee that Swansea have held out for, the 27-year-old's stats can perhaps, to an extent, justify such a huge outlay in an increasingly lavish transfer window.\n\nHere's how Sigurdsson's stats rate (excludes this season's numbers)\n\nAssists\n\nOver the last four Premier League seasons, only four players who racked up more assists than Sigurdsson's 26 - the yardstick by which No.10s should primarily be judged.\n\nThey are Cesc Fabregas (37), Mesut Ozil (33), Christian Eriksen (30) and Kevin De Bruyne (27).\n\nNot bad company to keep.\n\nSigurdsson's set-pieces have been held up as an important factor behind the Blues' determination to sign him, and he claimed 13 assists in total last term, with eight coming from dead-ball deliveries.\n\nGoals\n\nThe Everton target scored nine goals last season for relegation threatened Swansea, including three from the penalty spot.\n\nFive of those goals came against teams in the top six, meaning only Jamie Vardy scored more against top sides.\n\nSwansea scored 45 goals last season, with Sigurdsson directly involved in nearly half.\n\nThe attacking midfielder either scored or assisted a whopping 48.9% of the Swans' goals.\n\nOnly Jermain Defoe (58.6%) and Romelu Lukaku (50%) were involved in more for Sunderland and Everton respectively.\n\nThe former Tottenham man is also the Swans' all-time Premier League goalscorer and assist holder.\n\nHe's netted 34 goals in the top flight for the Welsh side as well as claiming 29 assists.\n\nFree-kicks\n\nSince making his Premier League debut in 2011, no player has scored more free-kicks than the Icelander.\n\nSigurdsson has curled home seven times from dead-ball situations to edge clear of Juan Mata and Robert Snodgrass' tally of six.\n\nRunning stats\n\nIn a football Would the Premier League really miss Stoke City?\" before Merson criticises their ambition, claiming \"you've got to have a go.\"\n\nThe video also highlights Marko Arnautovic's claim that West Ham are a bigger club than Stoke, after the Austrian left the Bet365 Stadium for the Hammers this summer.\n\nWith the word \"Ambition\" running through the video, the piece ends with Jese - whose arrival at Stoke takes the number of Champions League winners at the club to five, the most in the Premier League - giving a cheeky look to the camera.\n\nA fine effort all round.\n\npoll loading Will Jese {"timeCrawl": "20:45:00", "uri": "710536301", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:45:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "WalesOnline", "uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "id": "1272"}, "url": "http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/gylfi-sigurdssons-move-everton-leaves-13483977", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "Get rugby updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nThe parting of ways is by its very nature a painful experience and all the emotions associated with such an event will be felt by Swansea City fans as Gylfi Sigurdsson completes his move to Everton.\n\nThere will be sadness, anger, maybe even acceptance, all of which are perfectly understandable. But, in time, there will also be a realisation of the good fortune to have watched one of the finest players ever to wear a white shirt in his pomp.\n\nWhatever the Iceland international does, or does not, achieve at Goodison Park and beyond, there can be no denying the best football of his career to date has come in a Swansea jersey.\n\nIf you include his loan spell during the club's first Premier League campaign, he has scored 37 goals in 130 appearances. He departs as Swansea's record top-flight scorer, nine of his goals came last season in addition to 13 assists.\n\nHe was, and remains, a deadly set-piece operator, whether setting his own sights at goal or providing the ammunition for others.\n\nTo witness him in action has been to see one of the very best players the Premier League has to offer. His performances in a struggling team last season passed muster when compared to the likes of Christian Eriksen, Eden Hazard and Kevin de Bruyne - all of whom were in the skirmish for silverware at the other end of the table.\n\nNot that those facts will make his departure any easier to bear. If anything, they just highlight what a significant loss Sigurdsson is, not to mention the task that lies ahead in finding a replacement.\n\nFor their part, it is hard to know what more Swansea could have done in this particular transfer saga. They have rejected several offers and attempted to steer away interest, pushing the asking price North in an effort to keep hold of their star man.\n\nBut, when Sigurdsson told them he would not travel to America for their pre-season tour, the writing was on the wall.\n\nThere will be those who would say Swansea should have played hardball, and told a player with three years remaining on his contract that he was going absolutely nowhere.\n\nIn theory, that is fine, and it should be said that his late withdrawal from the trip was out of keeping with the professionalism and attitude he has shown during his time in SA1.\n\nBut it would have done neither party any good to have a man on the books with no desire to be at the club. Some will say it is a sad state of affairs that a player can hold that sort of power given they are club employees. They have a point, but nevertheless it is a reality of football in the 21st century.\n\nThe fact is, the deal is done and nothing can be done about that now. Instead it is worth taking a moment to pause and reflect on a Swansea career of the very-highest calibre.\n\nNot just in terms of quality, but in effort and sweat. No-one can doubt Sigurdsson gave anything other than his absolute all to the Swansea cause.\n\nHe ran himself into the ground for the Swans, last season he covered the most ground of any player, in any position, at any club in the Premier League.\n\nWithout him, you fancy Swansea would no longer be a top-flight club, that they would have succumbed to the drop in one of the last two seasons.\n\nThe ending may have left a bitter taste, but he could not have done much more.\n\nHe provided several moments of breathtaking brilliance to savour for years to come.\n\nFrom the free-kick at Wigan in his first spell, signalling that he was a sterling acquisition, to his final set-piece special at Old Trafford.It's difficult to pick a favourite goal or moment.\n\nThink of the free-kick to inspire the come-from-behind success over Arsenal in 2014, twice befuddling Wayne Hennessey from dead-ball situations in successive seasons at the Liberty.\n\nThere was a fantastic strike in a losing FA Cup cause at Blackburn, a wonderful controlled volley against Chelsea, a key finish in a home win over Norwich, the completion of a sweeping team move at Fulham.\n\nIn the end there are simply too many to list in one go, but one that stands out for this writer came during the crazy 5-4 win over Crystal Palace on a barmy night at the Liberty in November, and it had nothing to do with the stellar free-kick he tucked away.\n\nDuring the second half, Sigurdsson effortlessly brought down a high ball, killing it dead in one touch as Conor Wickham closed in near the touchline just inside the Palace half.\n\nSigurdsson feinted one way, then the other, stepped over the ball and feinted again. Wickham bought the dummy - Sigurdsson had barely taken a touch other than to bring the ball out of the air - and, realising his error, tried to readjust as the Swans man moved away from him.\n\nThe striker collapsed in a heap, having suffered a knee injury in trying to shift his weight back after being fooled by Sigurdsson.\n\nIt was cruel, and terribly unfortunate for poor Wickham, but it was an incredible exhibition of what Sigurdsson can to and the talent he possesses.\n\nSigurdsson made a fellow professional in one of Europe's top leagues look like a clumsy parks player rather than the quality top-flight striker Wickham is.\n\nNot many players can do that. It was brilliant and it was brutal.\n\nDebate has raged over the price tag. Is he worth \u00a340million, \u00a345million or \u00a350million?\n\nIn truth no-one is, but in the current market the figures spent elsewhere this summer suggest Swansea were more than within their rights to wring as much as they could from the deal.\n\nBut, when the furore dies down and time passes, all that will be left will be priceless memories of one of Swansea City's greatest players.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now", "id": "9561973", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Gylfi exit leaves transfer saga is almost over after Swansea City and Everton agreed a deal in principle for the Iceland international.\n\nNearly five weeks after Sigurdsson refused to travel on the Swans pre-season tour of America amid interest from the Toffees, he will get his move to Goodison Park.\n\nThe deal is understood to be for a fee of \u00a345million plus add-ons after a compromise was reached to bring the protracted negotiations to an end.\n\nSigurdsson is expected to travel to Merseyside on Wednesday to undergo a medical and complete the formalities of the transfer.\n\nEverton had previously had two bids rejected for the 27-year-old, who manager Ronald Koeman had pursued since his appointment as Toffees boss last summer.\n\nAll sides had become increasingly frustrated at how long it had taken to get a deal in place, with Swans head coach Paul Clement admitting that the process of making further additions to his squad was on hold pending an agreement over Sigurdsson.\n\nNow the Welsh club will be able to press on with plans to bring in new faces after securing a club-record transfer fee for the sale of a player.\n\nManchester City striker Wilfried Bony, West Brom's Nacer Chadli and Stoke's Joe Allen are the three leading targets for Clement and the Swans hierarchy, with the club hoping to seal deals for the first two names on that list in short order.\n\nSigurdsson has not played for the Swans since his sole pre-season outing against Barnet.\n\nIt was in the aftermath of that game that he informed Clement that he did not feel in the right frame of mind to travel with the rest of the squad.\n\nThe manner of his departure will leave a bitter taste for Swans fans as a player who, as recently as May, had spoken of being happy to remain at the Liberty if the club wanted to keep him.\n\nHis actions last month belied those words but he will leave a huge void to be filled in the closing weeks of the transfer window.\n\nSigurdsson scored nine goals and created 13 Swansea kicked off the new season with a goalless draw at Southampton last weekend.\n\nBut the hope will be that Swansea can bring in the attacking acquisitions Clement has spoken of as the window A productive five months in south Wales followed, with the attacking midfielder even scooping the Premier League Player of the Month award for March for his performances.\n\nA permanent transfer to the Swans collapsed, allowing Tottenham Hotspur to swoop and secure Sigurdsson's signature for a fee of \u00a38.8m.\n\nHe spent two seasons at White Hart Lane, scoring eight goals in 58 top-flight appearances, but then rejoined the Swans for a second spell as part of an exchange deal that saw defender Ben Davies go in the opposite direction.\n\nAnd having returned to the Swans, Sigurdsson once again became a key man thanks to his ability to score and create goals, as well his willingness to put in a shift for his team.\n\nHe was named Swans Player of the Year in both 2015/16 and 2016/17, while also becoming a firm fans' favourite at the Liberty Stadium.\n\nHe scored nine goals and contributed 13 assists as Swansea beat the drop in dramatic fashion in his last season in Wales.\n\nOn And it is no coincidence that as he's been forced to take more gambles in the market, he's attempted to mitigate the risk by returning to the contacts, players and the mentality that he knows best.\n\nBenitez is fully aware that Javier Manquillo comes to Newcastle after so-so loan spells with Sunderland and Liverpool. He knows that Joselu was unable to get in the Stoke squad and Mikel Merino had a stop-start season in the Bundesliga.\n\nBut he feels that he knows how to motivate players who came through the same Spanish system that he spent his early managerial career - and much of his embryonic professional life - working in. He feels that he knows how they think - and he'll be able to give them the right message to shock them back into some kind of form if their levels drop.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nBenitez's initial thoughts have always been to sign English players who know the league, but they have arrived with a sizeable premium this summer. The Tammy Abraham transfer, for example, was too expensive despite his lack of first team experience. Andre Gray and Harry Maguire were priced out of Newcastle's horizons early in the market.\n\nSo that left Newcastle looking to either the next tier of English players or overseas gambles. And Benitez feels it's better to go with what you know than take a risk on a player from another European league whose personality may be more difficult to unpick during what is a long season.\n\nWhile it might have been easy to bill this as a Spanish revolution - succeeding the French revolution that didn't get Newcastle far in the end - the truth is that it's more the case of the manager managing the resources he has. It's an interesting subplot into how Benitez has recalibrated his own expectations this season - and why it still feels unlikely that the manager will walk away.\n\nWhile national pundits have gravely predicted he won't last until Christmas, it feels highly unlikely - if you know the man - that he would walk away from this challenge and let down his squad and the city.\n\n\"What we have different to other Premier League clubs is the city behind the team. 52,000 behind the team,\" Benitez says.\n\n\"We have everything but because the money is so big in the Premier League now, it's not just (about) that. You need to do the right things in the other departments. If you make a couple of mistakes in the scouting department, it can cost you millions and you can't recover.\n\n\"The other teams: 75% of their squad is there. They have Premier League experience so they need three players. We knew that we needed more players, the question is could we get the players we wanted?\n\n\"Now we need to make sure we're improving the team, improving the squad. Some of the targets we had and players we were considering, teams at the bottom of the table paid \u00a320-25million for them. It was not normal but it has happened. It's the market.\n\n\"If you want to compete at the same level, you have to go to the market. I'm not saying whether this is fair or not. To me it's crazy. What we could have done to save some money, we didn't do it and now we're in a worse position. But still, I have confidence that if everything is fine, we can compete.\n\n\"One thing that I have - and I said it last year, and in the end we were right - is that we will compete to the end. Last year I said carry on and we won the last three games and won the title. Great. At Liverpool we won 10 and drew one of our last 11 games.\n\n\"In the Premier League you lose some games at the beginning and people are panicking. I don't want people panicking. You need to be consistent until the end, working to the very end. We will get better and better.\"\n\nThere's a measure of pressure on Newcastle to get points on the board early in the season, but Benitez is clear that there has to be calm this term - whatever happens.\n\n\"If we win three games in a row it'll be 'We have to win the title', if we lose three it'll be 'Oh, we are already relegated',\" he said.\n\n\"What I want it to be sure that my players realise that every game is going to be a challenge. Get three points, on to the next one. One game at a time - if we have this idea it'll be easier for us.\"\n\nMaking a tough situation easier has been a key theme for Benitez this summer. He will hope the signing of Joselu helps.\n\nRead More Newcastle United Transfer News", "id": "9329665", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Why NUFC have signed Spanish players this summer {"timeCrawl": "13:50:00", "uri": "710914933", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:50:00Z", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "source": {"title": "The New Indian Express", "uri": "newindianexpress.com", "id": "934"}, "url": "http://www.newindianexpress.com/sport/football/2017/aug/17/five-facts-on-icelandic-midfielder-gylfi-sigurdsson-1644534.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "LONDON: Five things on Icelandic midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson after he signed for Everton from Swansea on Wednesday:\n\n'Lamps' lights up Sigurdsson's world\n\nSigurdsson's role model is former Chelsea and England midfielder Frank Lampard. \"Frank Lampard was always the player I tried to model myself on,\" Sigurdsson told 'The Daily Telegraph' last year. \"The amount of goals he scored from midfield was incredible. On and off the pitch, he was what I wanted to be.\" Sigurdsson did get to work with a Frank Lampard but it was the former Chelsea star's dad Frank Senior when he was an academy coach at Reading. \"I was lucky enough to work with his father for a short period at Reading and that gave me an insight into why he is the player he is, why he has scored so many goals. He taught me a lot, mentally as much as anything.\"\n\nSigurdsson's 'incredible day'\n\nIceland and England rarely feature in the same news story save when there are fishing disputes but Sigurdsson and his team-mates will forever be recalled for beating the country which invented the 'Beautiful Game' 2-1 at Euro 2016 to progress to the quarter-finals. \"Making it to France was a fantastic achievement for the [Iceland] team and the country but beating England in the last 16 was an incredible day,\" Sigurdsson told Omnisport.\n\nFamily affair\n\nSigurdsson can thank his father Sigurdur Adalsteinsson and his elder brother Olafur for making the big time. Their father even rented a warehouse for the winter so his younger son's training regime was not interrupted. Olafur -- a capable golfer although earning qualification to the European Tour never materialised -- realised that Gylfi's build resembled that of a long distance runner so he would rely more on technique than a physical and robust game. However, Olafur had to teach himself before he could become Gylfi's coach. \"I was trying to find every VHS tape I could find and tried to learn how to coach a young kid,\" Olafur said. \"I did these exercises myself before I had Gylfi do them to see how it was.\"\n\nSum of his parts makes him special\n\nReading snapped up Sigurdsson but sent him out on loan first to Shrewsbury Town and then to Crewe Alexandra who were managed by compatriot Gudjon Thordarsson. It was he who played Sigurdsson in central midfield where he plays for his country although at several of his clubs he was often positioned out wide. \"He's probably not the best when it comes to defending or when it comes to attacking, but when you put them all together, he is one of the best midfield players in the world today,\" Iceland head coach Lars Lagerback recounted in the book 'Atvinnumadurinn Gylfi Sigurdsson' (Gylfi Sigurdsson, The Professional).\n\nSwansea tourist ambassador?\n\nSigurdsson may have left Swansea but it sounds as if the non-drinking non-smoking midfielder will miss the more tranquil life in Swansea as he waxed lyrical about the contrast with London, where he lived when he played for Spurs for two largely underwhelming years. \"The people here are so friendly, different to London where everyone is in a rush,\" he said last year. \"There's no traffic here, well hardly any, there's the beaches, in the summer this is just beautiful. Of course it rains a lot, but I'm not complaining.\" The bustling and lively atmosphere of Liverpool may come as a shock to him.", "id": "9701860", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Five {"timeCrawl": "13:47:00", "uri": "710349859", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T13:47:00Z", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "source": {"title": "betting.betfair.com", "uri": "betting.betfair.com", "id": "652"}, "url": "https://betting.betfair.com/football/premier-league/premier-league-betting-sigurdsson-transfer-swansea-everton-160817-206.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "\"Either way, Everton got their man in the end and there wasn't that much damage done. He's unlikely to be ready to play this weekend at Man City but I'd be surprised if he wasn't starting for the Blues by Gameweek 3 or 4.\"\n\nIt's finally gone through. Every summer there's a big transfer saga that lingers on for weeks before finally reaching its inevitable conclusion. When I wrote this piece over a month ago, the Iceland star was just 1/7 to move to Goodison Park. If the odds compilers, who rarely get these things wrong, were so adamant that the move was going to happen then why did it take a full month for it to go through?\n\nEither way, Everton got their man in the end and there wasn't that much damage done. He's unlikely to be ready to play this weekend at Man City but I'd be surprised if he wasn't starting for the Blues by Gameweek 3 or 4.\n\nAll well and good for Everton but where does this leave Swansea?\n\nIan Rush, who knows a thing or two about these matters said, \"In my personal opinion, I think Sigurdsson is irreplaceable. To lose that creativity, there isn't a player like that at Swansea at the moment.\"\n\nThat sounds about right and Paul Clement is now facing a nightmare scenario. He's lost his best player and whereas he may have money to replace him (or as close to that as possible) he's now lacking that other priceless commodity: time.\n\nThe [3.0] on Swansea to go down is looking good.\n\nOne of the more interesting aspects of modern-day football. There was another example of it today with Jese Rodriguez arriving at Stoke on loan from PSG which triggered the sale of Joselu to Newcastle. The Neymar exit leading to the Eriksen/Coutinho/Dembele arrival is still ongoing.\n\nWhat was meant to happen was that Ross Barkley left to Tottenham as Sigurdsson arrived and everyone was happy. But the England man's injury for up to six weeks has put a real spanner in the works. Spurs may decide there's little value in buying him now when they can't count on him till October. And Daniel Levy is smart enough to know that the longer the player goes unsold without signing a new contract, the cheaper he'll be. He's certainly not the 1/6 chance to move to White Hart Lane that he was a month ago.\n\nWhen Juventus sold Zinedine Zidane to Real Madrid almost two decades ago, they used the money (plus a bit more) to go out and buy Gianluigi Buffon, Lilian Thuram, Pavel Nedved and Marcelo Salas. Not bad business. A few titles followed their arrival.\n\nNow I'm not suggesting that the purchases of Jordan Pickford, Michael Keane, Davy Klassen, Sandro and Sigurdsson plus the free transfer signings Wayne Rooney and Cuco Martina are quite of the same standard as those four Juve got.\n\nBut it's hard to argue that between them they've more than made up for the exit of Romelu Lukaku. Few would also argue that this is Everton's best-ever squad in the Premier League era. [4.1] on the Toffees finishing Top 6 with Liverpool, Arsenal and even Chelsea looking rather vulnerable? Yes, please.\n\nIf Barkley stays at the club it will be virtually impossible to accommodate him, Sigurdsson, Klassen and Rooney into the same side. Not that that isn't a nice problem to have.\n\nWhat it might all mean is that Everton call it a day in terms of this transfer window and stop their pursuit of Olivier Giroud, valued at around \u00a320 million.\n\nYou could then have the busy Idrissa Gueye doing most of the running and tackling, Klassen in the so-called Number 8 position performing both offensive and defensive work and Sigurdsson playing either as an inside left forward or as a more traditional playmaker rather than in-the-hole, which would be a little further up the pitch.\n\nRooney would then play in-the-hole behind Sandro with any one of Morgan Schneiderlin, Tom Davies, Kevin Mirallas, Yannick Bolasie or Barkley being the 11th player depending on what system Ronald Koeman decides to play and how attacking he wants the side to be.\n\nThe nice thing for him is that Sigurdsson, Rooney and Barkley can all play in different positions. For example, both Rooney and the Iceland man could also play as a false number 9 if Sandro isn't available.\n\nIt should also mean the end of a 3-5-2 or 3-4-2-1 system being deployed for the simple reason that Everton have too many riches in midfield to only play three of them.\n\nExciting times ahead if you're a Toffee.", "id": "9490680", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Premier {"timeCrawl": "05:24:00", "uri": "710693112", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:24:00Z", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "source": {"title": "Sky Sports", "uri": "skysports.com", "id": "709"}, "url": "http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/10991459/rafael-benitez-facing-toughest-challenge-of-his-career-at-newcastle", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363222", "body": "Nick Wright\n\nComment and Analysis @nicholaspwright\n\nRafael Benitez facing toughest challenge of his career at Newcastle\n\nLast Updated: 16/08/17 6:12pm\n\nNewcastle suffered a 2-0 defeat to Tottenham on the opening day and there are problems aplenty facing Rafael Benitez. Nick Wright examines what could be the toughest challenge of his managerial career with help from one of the players who knows him best.\n\nRafael Benitez was eager to look at the positives after Newcastle's opening day defeat to Tottenham, praising his side's hard work and citing Jonjo Shelvey's sending off as the turning point. \"It was a great effort against a good team,\" he told Sky Sports. \"It was a pity that everything changed.\"\n\nHuddsf'ld vs Newcastle\n\nAugust 20, 2017, 12:30pm\n\nLive on\n\nGet Sky Sports Get a Sky Sports pass\n\nThe Spaniard will wonder what might have been if it wasn't for Shelvey's moment of madness, but the game also served as a reminder of the size of the task ahead. Newcastle only mustered one shot on goal before going down to 10 men. Benitez now faces three games without Shelvey and more still without injured defenders Paul Dummett and Florian Lejeune.\n\nIt is far from ideal after a frustrating summer in the transfer market. Spanish striker Joselu became Newcastle's sixth senior signing of the window when he sealed his \u00a35m switch from Stoke this week, but Benitez has made no secret of the fact that he expected more financial backing.\n\nMike Ashley promised to invest \"every last penny\" in the team when Newcastle clinched promotion last year, but expenditure has only just exceeded the \u00a330m fee they received for Moussa Sissoko last summer. In an interview with Sky Sports last week, the Newcastle owner insisted further signings will depend on player sales.\n\nIt's a blow to Benitez, whose existing squad only won the Championship thanks to Brighton's late-season slump, but his response has been one of defiance. \"I am not happy but for me it is a challenge,\" he said last week. \"Every manager wants to improve and have better players, but at the same time I am happy with the players I have because the team spirit was good last season.\"\n\nBenitez's determination to succeed at Newcastle is welcome news to the club and their supporters, and it comes as no surprise to those who know him best. \"What fans want above all is that you give everything for the shirt,\" former Spain winger Luis Garcia, who played under Benitez at Liverpool and Tenerife, tells Sky Sports.\n\nHe is protective of his players and his club. He always gives his best and Newcastle are seeing that now.\n\nLuis Garcia on Rafael Benitez\n\n\"Wherever Rafa has gone, he has always given everything. He has always supported his clubs, the charities, everything. He is always totally committed and that's what people love about him. He is protective of his players and his club. He always gives his best and Newcastle are seeing that now.\"\n\nGarcia, who won the Champions League with Benitez in 2005, has followed his old manager's Newcastle tenure closely. \"I sent him a message to congratulate him on promotion,\" he says. \"He's done a great job. It's difficult to be relegated and come back after only one year, especially when important players leave. Now he's trying to build a strong team because he knows it's going to be another tough year.\"\n\nA tough year becomes tougher in light of Newcastle's financial constraints, and the lack of star signings means Benitez's coaching abilities have taken on even more importance. This is not the first time the former Valencia and Liverpool manager has been asked to get the best out of what he's got. The question is whether he can achieve it again.\n\n\"He's the same manager he ever was,\" says Garcia. \"You cannot talk to Rafa about anything except football. Football is everything. Talking, learning and improving. He attends to every detail. Everything has to be under control. He loves that. He wants you to have the right preparations, the right rest, the right food, the right everything. New players have to adapt fast to the needs of the team.\"\n\nIt's up to Benitez to find the right chemistry on the training field, but the lack of firepower in attack is a separate concern. The Magpies scored 16 goals in 10 Premier League games under the Spaniard at the end of the 2015/16 campaign, but nine of those came from players who have since departed.\n\nDwight Gayle was prolific in the Championship but is yet to show the same kind of consistency in the top flight. Aleksandar Mitrovic and Ayoze Perez have scored just 22 Premier League goals in 104 appearances between them. Then there's new signing Joselu, who only found the net four times for Stoke last season and has never reached double figures for league goals in a single campaign.\n\nIt's easy to see why Benitez was so upset by Newcastle's failure to land Tammy Abraham, and now there are problems at the other end as well. Lejeune and Ciaran Clark marshalled Harry Kane impressively for the opening half hour on Sunday, but the Frenchman's ankle ligament damage leaves Benitez with another headache.\n\nFor an ambitious manager accustomed to competing at the top, it is unfamiliar territory. \"I know Rafa and I know he will not be planning just to fight to stay in the Premier League,\" says Garcia. \"I think he will be wanting to aim high, to try to get into those 10 positions at the top of the table and maybe fight for the Europa League places.\"\n\nBenitez can aim high and look at the positives, but much will depend on what happens in the remaining weeks of the transfer window. Right now, with Newcastle's squad in its current state and funds as limited as they are, the season ahead looks like an uphill battle.\n\nAlso See: Your club's record attendance Talks set for transfer changes Newcastle agree Joseulu deal Lejeune, Dummett sidelined", "id": "9616214", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Rafael Benitez facing toughest challenge of his career at Newcastle", "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "TOTTENHAM have had a bid accepted by Ajax for defender Davinson Sanchez that could be worth up to a club-record \u00a340m, according to Sky Sports.\n\nThe highly-rated centre-half was Ajax's player of the year last season and was also a target for Barcelona and Inter Milan.\n\nSanchez has won two caps for Colombia and scored six goals in his first season in Holland's Eredivisie, making a total of 43 appearances after signing last summer from Atletico Nacional.\n\nAjax had told Sky Sports News earlier this week that they had informed Sanchez they did not want to sell him this summer but have now been convinced to part with their prized asset.\n\nThe 21-year-old missed Ajax's first league game of the season - a 2-1 defeat to Heracles Almelo - with the management claiming he was not in the right state of mind to play.\n\nSanchez, who started against Manchester United in the Europa League final in May, would become Spurs' first signing of the summer.\n\nSpurs have been in the market for a new centre-half and pulled out of negotiations to sign Argentinian Juan Foyth from Estudiantes because Mauricio Pochettino felt they were demanding too much for the youngster.\n\nKevin Wimmer is a target for West Brom and his departure would leave Spurs short of cover at centre-half behind experienced options Toby Alderweireld, Jan Vertonghen and the versatile Eric Dier.\n\nSky sources understand no official bid has yet been made for Wimmer, but Albion have approached Spurs to ask whether they are prepared to sell.\n\nFederico Fazio has already left Spurs this summer, joining Roma for an undisclosed fee.\n\nThe news comes after Manchester City saw an \u00a318m bid for West Brom centre-back Jonny Evans rejected.\n\nBaggies boss Tony Pulis is adamant he doesn't want to lose his captain, and is keen on strengthening his defensive options whether or not Evans stays.\n\nStoke City also enquired about Wimmer's availability earlier in the window, but withdrew their interest after the \u00a37m signing of Bruno Martins Indi from Porto.\n\nWimmer, 24, who has two caps for Austria, joined Spurs from FC Koln in May 2015 and has made 14 Premier League appearances in two seasons.\n\nBurnley manager Sean Dyche says he is looking into the European market for a replacement for Andre Gray.\n\nBurnley sold Gray to Watford last week for \u00a318.5m and have been linked with Leeds striker Chris Wood and Deportivo's Florin Andone to replace him.\n\nSam Vokes filled the void of Gray by scoring two goals in Burnley's 3-2 victory over Chelsea last Saturday but Dyche is still looking for another striker.\n\nDyche wouldn't confirm his interest in the Romanian forward Andone but did confirm he had been monitoring players in Europe.\n\nHe said: \"We haven't got the support (scouting system) as some of the big clubs so when we do go into Europe it is important we have as much information as possible.\n\n\"There are certain situations we do have information on and there are certain situations we look at.\"\n\nDyche was also asked about whether Burnley had bids rejected for Hull's Sam Clucas and Leeds' Wood.\n\n\"We want to be private and confidential as best we can about our business. It's very rare messages come out of our club,\" added Dyche.\n\nElsewhere, Swansea have made an approach to Hull for midfielder Sam Clucas, according to Sky sources.\n\nHull are keen to retain Clucas as they target an immediate return to the Premier League and have so far rejected two bids from Burnley, with the second bid worth up to \u00a310m.\n\nSwansea manager Paul Clement wants to strengthen his squad following the \u00a345m departure of Gylfi Sigurdsson to Everton and is also targeting the signings of Wilfried Bony, Joe Allen and Nacer Chadli.\n\nClucas, who missed just one match in the Premier League last season, is contracted at the KCOM stadium until 2019 having signed a new three-year contract last August.\n\nFinally, Everton manager Ronald Koeman said he expects Gylfi Sigurdsson to boost the club's goal-scoring options after the attacking-midfielder completed his club- record move from Swansea City.\n\nSigurdsson signed a five-year contract after the two clubs agreed a fee, which British media reported to be around ($A73.5 million). The 27-year-old, who underwent a medical on Wednesday morning, played a key part in Swansea avoiding relegation last season, scoring nine goals and 13 assists.\n\n\"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in,\" Koeman told a news conference before the Europa League first-leg playoff against Croatian side Hajduk Split on Thursday.\n\n\"We knew we would lose (Romelu) Lukaku for this season and we need players who bring productivity to the team.\"\n\nLukaku moved to Manchester United last month, for a reported transfer fee of $A122.4 million.\n\nSigurdsson \"is the type of player with a lot of productivity,\" Koeman said. \"In my opinion, he is one of the best in the Premier League.\" The Iceland international is Everton's eighth new signing of the close season and he is eager to repay Koeman's faith in him.\n\n\"Hopefully I will continue to create goals and score goals for the team and contribute to the kind of success we're seeking at the club,\" he told evertontv. \"This is an ambitious club and it is clear we are moving in a really good direction.\n\n\"The most important thing is that this team keeps winning games and climbing the table - and does that throughout the season.\" The manager also confirmed he is still waiting to find out the extent of a hamstring injury midfielder Ross Barkley suffered in training last week. Barkley, who is in the final year of his contract, refused a new deal at the club and Koeman said last month he would be sold in the current transfer window. \"He stopped training last Monday,\" Koeman said.\n\n\"It looks like a hamstring injury, but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\"", "id": "9792791", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", {"timeCrawl": "15:19:00", "uri": "710393962", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T15:19:00Z", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "source": {"title": "Rediff News", "uri": "rediff.com", "id": "542"}, "url": "http://www.rediff.com/sports/report/epl-news-sanchez-could-be-out-of-arsenal-for-free-pix/20170816.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3364130", "body": "IMAGE: Alexis Sanchez's contract talk with Arsenal have come to a halt. Photograph: Paul Childsdetails/Action Images via Reuters\n\nArsenal risk losing striker Alexis Sanchez for free next season, according to manager Arsene Wenger, who confirmed the club have made no progress on a new contract for the Chilean striker.\n\nSanchez, 28, is currently in the final year of his contract. He has been linked with a move to Paris St Germain in the current transfer window.\n\n\"We have not progressed on that front,\" Wenger said in a news conference before Arsenal head to StokeCity on Saturday.\n\n\"At the moment, he is a player who goes into the final year of his contract and prepares for the season. We have not made any progress on the other front.\n\n\"It's not an ideal situation on the financial side and it demands some sacrifice ... but it doesn't mean the players who are in the final year of their contract will not extend their contract. We will work on that as well.\"\n\nWenger said Sanchez is still recovering from an abdominal strain but is expected to regain full fitness before the club's match in Liverpool on August 27.\n\n\"For Sanchez, it (Stoke) looks a little early, but he works hard in training,\" Wenger added. \"He should be available for next game against Liverpool.\n\n\"His recovery is going very well, he is working very hard. But you have to be very cautious. It was a muscle strain and (you have to be wary) not to have any setback on it.\"\n\nThe manager confirmed midfielders Jack Wilshere and Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, who are also in the final year of their contracts, are firmly in his plans for the current season.\n\nWilshere returned to action from a fractured leg during Arsenal Under-23's 3-2 win over DerbyCounty earlier this week.\n\n\"It's good that he is back and available,\" Wenger said.\n\n\"I think he needs games now. He might play again on Monday night. He is not far away now.\"\n\nArsenal began their campaign with a 4-3 home victory over LeicesterCity last weekend.\n\nBlow for Palace as Zaha ruled out for four weeks\n\nIMAGE: Wilfried Zaha of Crystal Palace in action. Photograph: Christopher Lee/Getty Images\n\nCrystalPalace winger Wilfried Zaha has been ruled out for four weeks after injuring his right knee in his team's 3-0 home defeat by promoted HuddersfieldTown in their opening Premier League game of the season on Saturday.\n\nThe Ivory Coast international, who has been Palace's Player of the Year for the last two seasons and signed a new five-year deal in May, left SelhurstPark with his knee in a brace and his absence is a major setback for manager Frank de Boer.\n\nBritish media reported that Zaha, who played the full 90 minutes, is likely to be out until after the upcoming international break and would miss Saturday's league trip to Liverpool and the home game against SwanseaCity on Aug. 26.\n\nThe 24-year-old would also miss a League Cup fixture against IpswichTown on Aug. 22 and Ivory Coast's home and away World Cup qualifiers against Gabon on Sept. 2 and Sept. 5, the reports said.\n\nPalace battled relegation all of last season, only narrowly avoiding the drop under then manager Sam Allardyce. The shock defeat by Huddersfield leaves them second-bottom in the table, above only West Ham United, after the opening round of fixtures.\n\nStoke sign forward Rodriguez on loan from PSG\n\nStoke City have signed forward Jese Rodriguez on a season-long loan from France's Paris St Germain, making him the Premier League side's sixth recruit of the transfer window.\n\nThe 24-year-old moved to PSG from Real Madrid for 22 million pounds ($28.3 million) at the start of last season but failed to settle. He scored twice in nine appearances before being loaned to Spanish side Las Palmas for the second half of the season.\n\nBefore joining PSG, Rodriguez spent nine seasons at Real, scoring 12 times in 62 La Liga appearances. He won the Champions League in 2014 and 2016 before a knee injury stalled his progress.\n\n\"He hasn't had the happiest of periods in his career in Paris, but he's still only a young man and is hungry to make a big impression in the Premier League,\" Stoke chief executive Tony Scholes told the club's website (www.stokecityfc.com).\n\nRodriguez follows Darren Fletcher, Kurt Zouma, Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting, Bruno Martins Indi and Josh Tymon to the club.\n\nStoke, who host Arsenal in the league on Saturday, were beaten 1-0 by Everton in their season opener at the weekend.\n\nKoeman backs record signing Sigurdsson to boost Everton attack\n\nEverton manager Ronald Koeman said he expects Gylfi Sigurdsson to boost the club's goal-scoring options after the attacking-midfielder completed his medical before he transfers from SwanseaCity.\n\nSigurdsson will move to GoodisonPark after the two clubs agreed a fee of about 45 million pounds ($57.84 million), a record for Everton, according to the British media.\n\nThe 27-year-old played a key part in Swansea's avoiding relegation last season, scoring nine goals and 13 assists.\n\n\"The latest is that he had his medical this morning. What I heard from the doctor was no problem,\" Koeman told a news conference before the Europa League first-leg playoff against Croatian side Hajduk Split on Thursday.\n\n\"We worked a long time to get this deal in and he was one of the key players to bring in. We knew would lose Lukaku for this season and we need players who bring productivity to the team.\n\nRomelu Lukaku moved to Manchester United last month, for a reported transfer fee of 75 million pounds.\n\nSigurdsson \"is the type of player with a lot of productivity, Koeman said. \"In my opinion, he is one of the best in the Premier League.\"\n\nThe manager also confirmed he is still waiting to find out the extent of a hamstring injury midfielder Ross Barkley suffered in training last week.\n\nBarkley, who is in the final year of his contract, refused a new deal at the club and Koeman said last month he would be sold in the current transfer window.\n\n\"He stopped training last Monday,\" Koeman said. \"It looks like a hamstring injury, but he needs to do more tests today and tomorrow to know exactly what the injury is.\"\n\nFollowing their Europa League encounter at GoodisonPark, Everton visit ManchesterCity in the league on Monday.\n\nGundogan returns in Man City friendly after eight-month layoff\n\nIlkay Gundogan made his first appearance in eight months for ManchesterCity on Tuesday when he came on as a second-half substitute against Girona in a friendly in Spain.\n\nThe German midfielder, who suffered knee ligament damage against Watford last December, could be in contention for a place in the squad for Monday's home tie against Everton.\n\nGirona beat City 1-0, with the 26-year-old coming on as a substitute in the 71st minute.\n\nCity beat promoted Brighton and Hove Albion 2-0 in their Premier League opener on Saturday.", "id": "9508134", Is that good enough for a club at the size of Newcastle? No, as far as I am concerned.\n\n\"So I am 100% behind Rafa Benitez . He has done his job, got them back into the Premier League at the first time of asking. You have banked god knows how many millions for being in the Premier League, or you will bank it over the next few years, now invest it and back me as a manager.\n\n\"I am with him all the way. It makes no sense to not go for it and protect your status. Not only that, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to look at what they have got and say it is not enough. {"eng-3364130": {"articles": {"totalResults": 306, "page": 1, "results": [{"wgt": 1, "timeCrawl": "02:49:00", "uri": "711217791", "lang": "spa", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:49:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "Mundo Deportivo", "uri": "mundodeportivo.com", "id": "2964"}, "url": "http://www.mundodeportivo.com/futbol/premier-league/20170816/43598497262/stoke-city-estadistica-champions-league-bojan-afellay-shaqiri-fletcher-jese.html", "eventUri": "eng-3364130", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "spa-1075068", "body": "El conjunto ingl\u00e9s cuenta con hasta 5 futbolistas que han levantado el prestigioso trofeo: Jes\u00e9, Bojan, Afellay, Shaqiri y Fletcher\n\nCon el fichaje de Jes\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez, el Stoke City ha conseguido una curiosa y sorprendente estad\u00edstica. El conjunto 'Potter' es quien cuenta con un mayor n\u00famero de jugadores en la Premier que han conseguido al menos una Champions League con hasta cinco futbolistas, dos de ellos ex-azulgranas. Adem\u00e1s del canario, tambi\u00e9n Bojan, Afellay, Shaqiri y Fletcher cuentan con el trofeo de mayor prestigio en Europa en su palmar\u00e9s.\n\nNo deja de ser llamativo que un club que jam\u00e1s ha disputado esta competici\u00f3n ocupe el primer lugar por delante de clubes como Chelsea (con 4 futbolistas), Manchester City (3), Manchester United (2) o Liverpool (1) -equipo que cuenta con 5 Champions League en su haber-.\n\nDarren Fletcher fue el primero en conseguir el mayor t\u00edtulo europeo. En la temporada 2007-08 en el Manchester United, el centrocampista consigui\u00f3 levantar el trofeo tras una ag\u00f3nica tanda de penaltis ante el Chelsea. El futbolista ingl\u00e9s ha recalado este mismo verano en el Stoke con la carta de libertad procedente del West Brom.\n\nLa temporada siguiente fue el turno del Barcelona, que se proclam\u00f3 campe\u00f3n tras vencer precisamente al United por dos tantos a cero. Aquella plantilla contaba con Bojan Krkic, quien dos a\u00f1os m\u00e1s tarde repiti\u00f3 \u00e9xito al conseguir la Champions del 2010-11 de nuevo ante los 'red devils'. El delantero fich\u00f3 en 2014 desde el club cul\u00e9 y ha retornado a Stoke-on-Trent tras su cesi\u00f3n la temporada pasada en el Mainz 05. All\u00ed Bojan hizo historia al ser el primer espa\u00f1ol en marcar en las cuatro grandes ligas.\n\nEn aquel segundo triunfo europeo coincidi\u00f3 con Ibrahim Afellay. El holand\u00e9s levant\u00f3 aquella Champions que le dej\u00f3 un gran sabor de boca, siendo protagonista en las semifinales contra el Real Madrid. El internacional lleg\u00f3 libre al Stoke en 2015 procedente del Bar\u00e7a tras salir por la puerta de atr\u00e1s del club azulgrana.\n\nEn el a\u00f1o 2012-13 qui\u00e9n rein\u00f3 en el viejo continente fue el Bayern de M\u00fanich. El club b\u00e1varo venci\u00f3 en una final con acento alem\u00e1n al Borussia Dortmund por un apretado 2-1. Xherdan Shaqiri formaba parte de aquella plantilla siendo un suplente de lujo por detr\u00e1s de Arjen Robben. Hace dos temporadas dej\u00f3 el Inter de Mil\u00e1n para convertirse en \u00eddolo de los 'Potters' siendo un traspaso r\u00e9cord para el club (17 millones de euros).\n\nEl \u00faltimo en sumarse a esta lista es Jes\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez. El extremo jugar\u00e1 como cedido este a\u00f1o en Inglaterra procedente del PSG. El canario, al igual que Bojan, cuenta con dos Champions en su haber. Ambas con el Real Madrid. conseguidas ante el rival de la ciudad, el Atl\u00e9tico. La primera cosechada en 2013-14 y la segunda dos a\u00f1os despu\u00e9s.\n\nPese al dato, no dejan de ser futbolistas que tuvieron una trascendencia testimonial en los \u00e9xitos cosechados en sus equipos. Prueba de ello es otro dato demoledor: entre los cinco integrantes de esta lista tan s\u00f3lo acumulan 1 minuto en las finales de Champions League en las que se convirtieron en campeones.
